(10:00) A.M. on any day. (2000 Code § 3-326; amd. Ord. 1080, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-
8-2008)
   E.   Permit any person not an employee to remain on the licensed premises
where the consumption of alcoholic beverages is usually permitted as a part of
the operation of the private club after two fifteen o'clock (2:15) A.M. on any
day of the week and before the next regular opening hour.
   F.   Serve to or allow any intoxicated person to consume any alcoholic
beverages on the premises so licensed.
   G.   Permit an intoxicated person to be or to remain on the licensed
premises.
   H.   Permit a person under the age of twenty one (21) years to consume
intoxicating alcoholic beverages on the premises.
   I.   Serve or permit to be served any intoxicating alcoholic beverages to
any person under the age of twenty one (21) years.
   J.   Permit a person under the age of twenty one (21) years to serve any
intoxicating alcoholic beverages on the licensed premises. (2000 Code § 3-326)
3-3-21: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Authority To Suspend: The license review board may suspend for not more
than fifteen (15) days, or revoke, licenses issued hereunder if, after public
hearing, as hereinafter provided, the board finds that the holder of the
license has violated any of the provisions of this code.
   B.   Investigation; Complaint; Hearing: The chief of police shall
investigate complaints concerning private clubs and if he finds a violation of
the provisions has been committed, he shall file a complaint with the city
clerk setting forth the alleged acts constituting the violation. Upon the
filing of such complaint, the city clerk shall fix a date for hearing the
complaint by the license review board and shall cause to be served upon the
licensee a copy of the complaint and notice of the time and place of the
hearing. The complaint and notice of hearing shall be served upon the manager,
operator, partner or person shown on the license as having supervisory control
over the premises of the private club, or if such person may not be found, by
mailing the same by registered mail, addressed to such person at the licensed
premises. At the hearing thereon, the complainant, the licensee, or any
interested person may be present and present such evidence as may be relevant
and material. If at the conclusion of such hearing, the license review board
finds that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this code, the
board shall suspend for not more than fifteen (15) days, or revoke, the license
issued to the private club. Upon suspension or revocation, the licensee shall
immediately cease operation as a private club. (2000 Code § 3-327)
3-3-22: OTHER LAWS APPLICABLE:
   The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to exempt any person,
firm, corporation, or association operating a private club from compliance with
any other applicable ordinance of the city not in conflict herewith. (2000 Code
§ 3-328)
3-3-23: PENALTY:
   Any person, partnership, corporation or association, or officer, director,
stockholder, owner or manager of any private club who violates any provision of
this chapter is guilty of an offense, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
punished as provided in section 1-1-8 of this code. (2000 Code § 3-329)
TITLE 4
ANIMALS
CHAPTER 1
ANIMALS AND FOWL; GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
4-1-1: Definitions
4-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context otherwise requires:
             A structure or area of structural soundness with three sides, a waterproof roof,
             solid floor, adequate bedding material, positioned to allow for protection from
             north and west winds, proper ventilation, and which is suitable for the species,
             age, condition, size and type of animal which is safe and protects each animal
ADEQUATE     from injury, precipitation, direct sunlight, adverse effects of extreme heat or
SHELTER:     cold, enables the animal to be clean and dry, and has sufficient room for the
             animal to move about freely and to lie comfortably while allowing the retention
             of the animal's body heat. Wildlife, livestock, and other non-domesticated
             animals normally residing outdoors shall be only required to have appropriate
             shelter from extreme weather through natural or artificial means available to it
             to protect the animal.
ANIMAL       The Chief of Police or his/her designee; or any City of Seminole official or
CONTROL      entity charged with the responsibility of animal control or designee, to include,
AUTHORITIES: but not limited to any third-party authorized to provide animal control
             operations or services.
             The facility designated and/or operated by the City or its designee, including
             the actual premises where animals are regularly kept, or places where the Animal
             Control authority or its designee may designate, for the purpose of keeping or
ANIMAL       impounding stray, neglected, abused or seized animals and provide adequate care
WELFARE      before disposal of the animals as outlined in this chapter. The Animal Welfare
CENTER:      Center includes a portion of the facility to provide for animal adoptions,
             education, citizen involvement, and spaying or neutering of animals before
             adoption from the facility. This shall include the premises commonly known as the
             "Animal Shelter."
             A nonprofit organization which is approved by the City Council to provide animal
             control services and/or operate the Animal Welfare Center and has a primary
             purpose of providing for the welfare and/or protection of animals. Approval may
             be refused to any animal welfare group if the City Council determines that the
             animal welfare group or one of its members meets one or more of the following:
ANIMAL       A.   Has a record of cruelty to animals;
WELFARE      B.   Is under eighteen (18) years of age;
GROUP:       C.   Has committed substantiated acts of neglect or harassment to animals;
             D.   Owns other animals which are in violation of any requirement of this Title;
             E.   Refuses to comply with any contractual requirement with the City of Seminole
             with regard to the provision of animal control and welfare services;
             F.   Lacks adequate housing and/or fencing to contain the animals; or
             G.   Has a conviction in any Court for any violation of this Title.
AT HEEL:     Within a radius of ten feet (10') of the owner and obedient to the owner's
             commands.
             A phrase indicating that an animal is:
AT LARGE:    A.   Off the premises of its owner and not securely and physically restrained by
             means of harness, leash, or other device designed to restrain such animal.
             C.   Not confined on the premises of the owner or at heel on said premises.
CHICKEN      A small structure or enclosure where chickens nest, roost or perch and may
COOP:        include feeding and watering devices.
CHICKEN RUN: An enclosed area physically connected to the coop where chickens are able to walk
             or run about which may include feeding and watering devices.
             Any business or establishment, whether operated separately or in connection with
COMMERCIAL   another business or establishment that keeps, boards, sells, shows, and/or trains
KENNEL:      dogs or cats for profit. This does not include animal hospitals or veterinary
             clinics.
CONFINED ON  Means and indicates that an animal is securely and physically restrained on and
THE          within the premises of the owner by means of fences, leashes, walls, or other
PREMISES:    devices designed to prevent the animal from leaving those premises.
             Any animal whose behavior, temperament, size, or any combination thereof, when
             considered under the totality of the circumstances, including the nature of the
             surrounding area, constitutes a reasonable risk of injuring a human or animal or
DANGEROUS    damaging personal or real property. That behavior includes, but is not limited
ANIMAL:      to, an animal biting or attacking or attempting to attack a human or another
             animal. However, this definition shall not apply to any animal that has been
             subject to provocation or if the victim has been trespassing, as defined in
             Section
             10-2-13 of this Code, upon the animal owner's premises.
             Any domestic species of cattle, sheep, swine, goats, llamas, or horses, or any
DOMESTICATED other animals which are normally and have historically, been kept and raised on
ANIMAL:      farms in the United States, and used or intended for use as food or fiber, or for
             improving animal nutrition, breeding, management, or production efficiency, or
             for improving the quality of food or fiber; in permitted A-1 zones only.
             The term "exotic wildlife" means any of the following animals:
             A.   A lion, tiger, leopard, ocelot, cheetah, margay, lynx, jaguar, jaguarundi,
             or any and all other felines (family Felidae), except the domestic cat (species
             Felis domesticus);
             B.   A grizzly bear, or any and all other bears (family Ursidae);
             C.   A wolf, fox, jackal, hyena, or any other canines (family Canidae), except
             the domestic dog (species Canis familiaris);
             D.   Any and all venomous reptiles (venomous members of the class Reptilia),
EXOTIC       including without limitation, Gila monster (species Heloderma suspectum), beaded
WILDLIFE:    lizard (species Heloderma horridum), and venomous snakes (venomous members of the
             suborder Serpentes);
             E.   Any and all crocodiles, caimans, or alligators (family Crocodilia);
             F.   Gorillas, orangutans, baboons, macaques, or chimpanzees; or any non-human
             primate (order Primata) that is not licensed pursuant to the provisions of this
             Title; or any non-human primate (order Primata) that test positive for
             tuberculosis or herpes B;
             G.   Cassowaries (genus Casuarius);
             H.   Any cross-breed or hybrid which includes any animal defined as exotic
             wildlife in subsections (1)(a) through (g), inclusive, of this definition.
             A dog or cat that was either born in the wild or has reverted to a wild state due
FERAL DOG OR to abandonment or lack of domestication and has no owner. Any feral dog or cat
CAT:         which has been captured and neutered or spayed and returned to the wild shall
             continue to be classified as a feral animal.
             Any premises owned by an individual who works with or under the direction of an
             approved Animal Welfare Group registered with the City who will take in stray or
             unowned dogs and/or cats, or other animals, for the purpose of providing
FOSTER HOME: temporary care up to twelve (12) months for each animal. A temporary care
             extension may be requested for up to an additional six (6) months for an animal,
             if there is proof of a documented medical condition that requires the extended
             temporary housing of the animal.
             The term "native wildlife" means any and all species of wildlife that are
NATIVE       indigenous to or occur naturally within the State, including, but not limited to,
WILDLIFE:    mountain lion (cougar), bobcat, coyote, red fox, gray fox, black bear, and
             American alligator.
             The term "neutered" means a process performed by a veterinarian or other person
NEUTERED:    authorized by law, which removes the reproductive organs of any male animal as
             defined in 4 O.S. §§ 499 et. seq. Dog and Cat Sterilization Act.
             An animal that:
             A.   Damages the property of anyone other than its owner, including, but not
NUISANCE:    limited to, scratches or digs about any flower bed, garden, tilled soil, vines,
             shrubbery, or small plants and in so doing injures them;
             B.   Habitually prowls around, on, or over any premises not the property of its
             owner to the frequent annoyance of the owner or occupant of those premises;
             C.   Overturns any garbage can or other container of waste products, or scatters
             the contents of the same;
             D.   Chases or kills any domesticated animals or domesticated birds;
             E.   Annoys or disturbs any person by loud and frequent barking, howling,
             yelping, or causes noise in an excessive, continuous or untimely fashion/manner
            so as to interfere with the reasonable use and enjoyment of neighboring private
             premises;
             F.   An animal that habitually or repeatedly chases, snaps at, or barks at
             pedestrians, joggers, dogs walked by owners, bicycles or vehicles;
             G.   Disturbs the rights of, threatens the safety of or injures a member of the
             general public or interferes with the ordinary use and enjoyment of his property.
             Any person possessing legal title to any animal or, possessing no legal title, is
             identified by City pet license or microchip registration, or a person who keeps
OWNER:       or harbors the animal in excess of fourteen (14) days without delivering the
             animal to its proper owner or the Animal Welfare Center, provides food or water
             regularly for the animal, or provides routine or ongoing non-emergency medical
             care for the animal.
PRIVATE      Any premises which exceeds the allowable number of dogs and/or cats as described
KENNEL:      in this section, and the animals are kept as pets and not used for any other
             purpose other than companionship for their owners.
             Any facility operated by a non-profit Animal Welfare Group where dogs and/or
             cats, or other animals, are kept and are provided temporary housing for an animal
RESCUE       for up to twelve (12) months and up to an additional six (6) months if there is
KENNEL:      proof of a documented medical condition that requires the extended temporary
             housing, and care for the purpose of placing them into a permanent home, except
             for a designated foster home.
             A dog that has been individually trained to do work or perform tasks for the
             benefit of an individual with a disability, including an individual with a
             disability, including a physical, sensory, psychiatric, intellectual, or other
             mental disability. The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) rules state that
SERVICE      other animals, whether wild or domestic, do not qualify as service animals. Dogs
ANIMAL:      that are not trained to perform tasks that mitigate the effects of a disability,
             including dogs that are purely for emotional support, are not service animals.
             Therapy, comfort, and/or emotional support animals are often a great asset to
             those they work with. However, they are not service animals, and may not enjoy
             the same rights, privileges and/or access to restricted areas as is allowed under
             federal or State law, as a service animal.
             The term "spayed" means a process performed by a veterinarian or other person
SPAYED:      authorized by law, which removes the reproductive organs of any female animal as
             defined in 4 O.S. §§ 499 et. seq. Dog and Cat Sterilization Act.
UNPROVOKED:  An act of aggression towards an animal or human that occurs without apparent
             cause, reason, prompting or motivation.
 
(2000 Code § 4-101; amd. Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
CHAPTER 2
ADMINISTRATION
SECTION:
4-2-1: Authority Of Animal Welfare Personnel; Inspection
4-2-2: Duties Of Animal Welfare Supervisor
4-2-3: Fees, Charges, And Deposits
4-2-4: Obtaining Release Of Impounded Animals
4-2-5: Disposition Of Animals Not Retrieved By Owners
4-2-6: Owner Responsibilities For Lost And Missing Animals
4-2-7: Refusal To Redeem Impounded Animal
4-2-8: Quarantine Of Animals Which Injure Persons
4-2-9: Destruction Or Impoundment Of Animal Suspected Rabid
4-2-10: Animals That Die After Injuring A Person; Procedure
4-2-11: Registration Of Dogs And Cats; License Required
4-2-12: License Not Required; Exemptions
4-2-13: Term Of License
4-2-14: License Application
4-2-15: Rabies Vaccination
4-2-16: Issuance Of Tags And Certificates
4-2-17: Owner Must Attach License
4-2-18: Tag Or Certificate Must Be Shown
4-2-19: Removal Of Registration Tags Prohibited
4-2-20: Lost And Destroyed Tags
4-2-21: Counterfeit And Imitation Tags
4-2-22: Authority To Euthanize
4-2-23:    Penalties
4-2-1: AUTHORITY OF ANIMAL WELFARE PERSONNEL; INSPECTION:
   A.   Enforcement Authority. Animal Welfare personnel shall have an
obligation to assist with enforcing the provisions of this Title when
circumstances permit. Although they shall not be possessed with the powers of
arrest or to issue citations, they shall be authorized to take any necessary
action regarding animals that are subject to impound for the welfare and safety
of the general public, as well as to the animal. They shall be further
authorized to submit a verified Citizen Complaints for the prosecution of
offenses for any violation of this Title.
   B.   Use of Force. Animal Welfare personnel are specifically authorized to
use whatever means necessary to impound animals in violations of the provisions
of this Title, including, but not limited to, the use of tranquilizer guns.
When circumstances are required, they may seek the assistance of police to
assist with the enforcement of these provisions.
   C.   Inspection of Licensed Kennels. The Office of Code Enforcement or
designee may, upon complaint or on their own initiative, inspect any structure
or place licensed or suspected of operating an unlicensed kennel. Any licensed
kennel shall receive at least one (1) inspection annually at each licensed or
registered location.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-2: DUTIES OF ANIMAL WELFARE SUPERVISOR:
The Animal Welfare Supervisor (or equivalent individual designated by the
Animal Welfare Group) shall have the following duties and responsibilities:
   A.   Supervise all Animal Welfare Officers, Employees, Personnel and
Volunteers as may be applicable;
   B.   Staffing, administration and maintenance of the Animal Welfare Center;
   C.   Seize and retrieve all animals in violation of the provisions of this
Title or any animal that is or will be without proper care because of injury,
illness, incarceration or running at-large, and shall impound them at the
Animal Welfare Center;
   D.   Incapacitate or destroy by any means necessary any dangerous animal
when causing an immediate threat to a human or another animal after a
reasonable attempt is unable to be captured;
   E.   Provide suitable and necessary sustenance and care for all animals
while impounded in their custody;
   F.   Release an impounded animal to its owner after all impoundment fees and
room and board charges are paid in full. The Animal Welfare Shelter Manager, or
designated employees, shall have the discretion and authority to waive or
suspend part or all of the fees based on documentable, reasonable and necessary
needs to allow an animal to be returned to its owner;
   G.   Account for all income and expenditures. Transfer all required proceeds
from sales, fees, charges, and deposits to the City Clerk.
   H.   Perform all other obligations as may be set forth by contractual
agreement with the City;
Nothing in this section shall prevent the Animal Welfare Supervisor or his
designee from seizing and/or forfeiting an impounded animal pursuant to any
other provision of the City ordinances or State law.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-3: FEES, CHARGES, AND DEPOSITS:
   A.   Fees, charges and/or deposits may be charged for each animal for the
following costs and services:
      1.   Impoundment of each animal;
      2.   Handling fee for special equipment or services;
      3.   Room and boarding charge;
      4.   Sterilization fee;
      5.   Veterinarian fees;
      6.   Quarantine fees for animals that have injured persons or suspected
to have rabies;
      7.   Impound fees for animals declared dangerous or awaiting the
determination    process;
      8.   Dead animal disposal fee;
      9.   Pet license fee;
      10.   Kennel permit and inspection fees;
      11.   Replacement license or tag;
      12.   Other fees and costs not identified on the fee schedule but deemed
necessary and appropriate for the care and welfare of the animal.
   B.   Said fees shall be set administratively and based upon the actual cost
of providing said services. The fee schedule shall be placed on file in the
City Clerk's office and reviewed annually.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-4: OBTAINING RELEASE OF IMPOUNDED ANIMALS:
Owners of impounded animals may retrieve or otherwise obtain the release of
their animals from the Animal Welfare Center only after the applicable payment
of fees and costs as set forth in the fee schedule, subject to any waiver as
may be approved. (Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-5: DISPOSITION OF ANIMALS NOT RETRIEVED BY OWNERS:
   A.   Disposition of Animals. Except as hereinafter provided, any animal
which is impounded by the City pursuant to the provisions contained herein,
shall be adopted, rehomed or otherwise disposed of after five (5) business days
from the time of its impoundment. Animal shelter authorities shall have
discretion to dispose of any animal taken into custody in a manner consistent
with this policy, to include, but not limited to, adoption, rehoming, transfer
to a responsible third party or euthanasia. Every effort shall be made to
preserve each animal in lieu of euthanasia with due consideration given to the
health, safety and welfare of the public and the maximum number of animals
permitted in the shelter facility.
   B.   Time Period Defined. For the purposes of this section, the five (5)-day
time period shall begin at eight o’clock (8:00) a.m. the day following the
animal's intake into the facility. Calculation of the five (5) business days
shall not include weekends, holidays, or other days the shelter is not open to
the public.
   C.   Exemptions. Impounded kittens and puppies which enter the shelter in
groups of three (3) or more and are under four months of age without a known
owner or mother may, at the discretion of the shelter staff, be exempted from
any required hold times prior to their release. The age of four (4) months
shall be determined by the eruption of the animal's adult teeth.
   D.   Seized Animals; Procedure. Animals held at the Animal Welfare Center
due to legal seizure, arrest, medical situation, protective custody seizures,
or other legal means involving law enforcement requests shall be returned to
the owners or legal representative as soon as possible. Upon verification that
the animal's owner has been notified of its impoundment, the five (5)-day
holding time referenced in the above section shall apply as if the animal were
impounded for other reasons.
   E.   Extension of Time for Identified Animals. An animal's impoundment
period will be automatically increased by forty-eight (48) hours should that
impounded animal display a tag, microchip or markings indicating that:
      1.   The owner of such animal is a City resident; or
      2.   Such animal displays a tag which indicates it is vaccinated against
rabies.
   F.   Retention of Animal by Court Directive. Should it be determined that
the owner of an impounded animal has demonstrated the inability to properly
care for said animal, or is experiencing a situation that prohibits him from
reclaiming or arranging for the release of the animal in a timely and
reasonable manner, the Animal Welfare Supervisor may seek an order from a judge
of competent jurisdiction for the release of the animal into the care and
custody of the Animal Welfare Center in order that the highest level of long-
term care and safety of the animal may be provided for. The Court may direct
the forfeiture of any animal upon satisfactory proof that the animal has been
subject to gross neglect or abuse.
   G.   Disposal or Destruction of Impounded Animals; Procedure. The manner and
method of disposal or destruction of an impounded animal shall be directed by
the Animal Welfare Supervisor or a licensed veterinarian. Such disposal may
include, but is not limited to, adoptions, euthanasia, or transfer to another
animal welfare group, an animal rescue group or other animal welfare facility.
For domestic animals other than dogs and cats, sale by auction may be utilized
as outlined in State law. No live animals shall be released or sold to any
facility for educational, scientific and/or medical research. Notwithstanding
any provisions of this Title, no animal suspected of being rabid or otherwise
diseased shall be destroyed until such destruction is recommended by a licensed
veterinarian.
   H.   Adoption Criteria. Adoption or sale may be refused to anyone determined
by the Animal Welfare Group or their designated authority based upon one or
more of the following:
      1.   Has a record of cruelty to animals;
      2.   Is not of sufficient age or lacks the capacity to properly care for
an animal;
      3.   Has committed verified acts of neglect, abuse or harassment to an
animal;
      4.   Lacks adequate housing, fencing or other necessary facilities to
contain or properly care for the animal;
      5.   Has a conviction in Municipal Court for a violation of this Title.
      6.   Does not agree to comply with any and all other requirements of
adoption as mandated by the Animal Welfare Group policies and procedures;
      7.   Does not meet any other established criteria to be a responsible pet
owner as set forth by applicable policies or guidelines.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-6: OWNER RESPONSIBILITIES FOR LOST AND MISSING ANIMALS:
   Proper custody and control of all animals is an owner responsibility.
Locating lost or missing animals is the sole responsibility of the owner. The
Animal Shelter Facility, it's employees or its designees shall not be
responsible in any fashion for the disposition of impounded animals past the
time permitted for the owner to recover the animal. An owner shall be obligated
to timely inquire of the Animal Welfare Facility to determine whether a missing
animal is in its custody and retrieve said animal. Failure to do so may forfeit
the right of the owner to recover the animal should other lawful disposition
occur. In all instances, the owner of any ill, injured or disabled animal shall
be liable for any additional fees and costs incurred with its impoundment.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-7: REFUSAL TO REDEEM IMPOUNDED ANIMAL:
   It shall be unlawful for the owner, possessor, harborer or keeper of an
animal which has been impounded by the Animal Welfare Center to refuse to
respond or to make arrangements to redeem an impounded animal as soon as
reasonably possible once they have been notified of the impoundment.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-8: QUARANTINE OF ANIMALS WHICH INJURE PERSONS:
   When any animal capable of carrying or transmitting rabies or other disease
bites or otherwise injures a person, or is suspected of having rabies, such
animal shall be quarantined as directed in the State Department of Health
Zoonotic Disease Control Rules, OAC title 310, chapter 599, pursuant to the
authority contained in 63 O.S. §§ 1-508 et seq.
   It shall be unlawful to refuse to confine an animal who has bitten a person
("bite animal"). Each day that a violation or failure to comply exists shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-9: DESTRUCTION OR IMPOUNDMENT OF ANIMAL SUSPECTED RABID:
   A.   Rabid Animal. Any animal which has contracted rabies shall immediately
be destroyed.
   B.   Unvaccinated Animal. Any unvaccinated animal which has been bitten by
another animal which is rabid shall, at the option of the owner:
      1.   Immediately be destroyed; or
      2.   Be impounded for not less than six (6) months in a licensed
veterinarian's hospital or other designated quarantine location for the
purposes of observation and such animal shall be vaccinated at least three (3)
days prior to release. All costs of that impoundment are to be paid by the
owner of the impounded animal.
   C.   Vaccinated Animal. Any effectively vaccinated animal which is bitten by
a rabid animal shall be immediately revaccinated and restrained by leashing and
confinement, for a period of at least 90 days, by the owner.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-10: ANIMALS THAT DIE AFTER INJURING A PERSON; PROCEDURE:
   A.   Ten Day Period; Notification. Should any animal bite or inflict by
other means an open wound on a person and cause an exposure to saliva or other
potentially infectious tissue, and thereafter die for any reason within ten
(10) days, the owner of that animal must notify the Animal Welfare Supervisor
and secure an examination of the animal's head by an authorized agency of the
City, County, or State qualified to give such examinations. Should any animal
die while impounded at the Animal Shelter, the Animal Welfare Supervisor shall
follow the procedure as set forth in this section.
   B.   Examination of Remains. The head of the animal shall be delivered to
such examining agency within a period of not more than twelve (12) hours
subsequent to its death, if the death occurs at night; and no more than three
(3) hours subsequent to the death if such occurs between the hours of five
o’clock (5:00) a.m. and six o’clock (6:00) p.m.
   C.   Report of Examination. Upon receipt of the examination report, the
owner must immediately transmit the results thereof to the person bitten or if
such person is a minor, to the minor's parent, guardian, or other authorized
adult relative. A copy of the written examination report shall also be
forwarded to the Animal Welfare Supervisor.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-11: REGISTRATION OF DOGS AND CATS; LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   License Required. Every person within the City owning, possessing,
controlling, harboring, or keeping any dog or cat over six (6) months of age
shall procure a pet license tag for each dog or cat from the Animal Welfare
Center or authorized agent, as long as ownership of the dog or cat continues,
or within thirty (30) days after acquiring or bringing into the City any dog or
cat over the age of six (6) months, and shall continue to procure such tags as
required herein, so long as ownership of the dog or cat continues.
   B.   License fees shall be waived or reduced for the following:
      1.   Service animals shall not be charged a pet license fee.
      2.   Senior citizens (fifty-five (55) years of age and above), active-
duty military, and military veterans shall receive a fifty percent (50%)
discount on a pet license fee.
      3.   Adopted animals from the City shall receive a waiver of the first-
year pet license. The Animal Welfare Center shall provide a license tag for the
first year at no cost which shall be displayed on the animal at all times.
   C.   Issuing Entities. It shall be permissible for voluntary licensing
stations to be operated by nonprofit organizations or veterinary hospitals,
allowing such voluntary licensing stations to retain four dollars ($4.00) of
the pet licensing fees with the remainder of such fee amounts to be retained by
the City.
   D.   Transfer of License. When the dog or cat has a valid license from any
county or from another city within the State, proof of such licensing shall be
submitted to the Animal Welfare Center and an animal license tag shall be
issued to the owner for a fee established administratively.
   E.   Transfer of Ownership within City. Within thirty (30) days of the
transfer or sale of a dog or cat with a valid City license, the new owner shall
purchase a new pet license from the Animal Welfare Center should the new owner
reside within the city limits.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-12: LICENSE NOT REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
The requirements of a pet license shall not apply to dogs or cats found within
the City under any of the following conditions:
   A.   When the dog or cat is owned by, or in the care of, any person who is a
nonresident or who is traveling through the City, or who is temporarily within
the City limits, for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days;
   B.   When the dog or cat is brought into the City and kept therein for a
period not exceeding thirty (30) days, for the exclusive purpose of entering
the dog or cat in any bench show, dog exhibition, field trials or other
competition;
   C.   When the dog or cat is brought or sent into the City for the exclusive
purpose of receiving veterinary care in any veterinary clinic or animal
hospital.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-13: TERM OF LICENSE:
   Each pet license issued shall be effective for a one or three year period,
at the option of the owner, and shall be issued upon payment of all required
fees, charges, and penalties established administratively, and upon compliance
with all conditions required for issuance of a license.
   A new license issued for a period commencing after the first of any month
shall be effective from that date until the last day of the same month in the
following years, as appropriate.
   Any license renewal shall be effective from the first day of the month
following the expiration date of the license being renewed.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-14: LICENSE APPLICATION:
   The owner shall provide, at the time application is made and upon standard
printed forms of an application provided for such purpose, the Owner's name,
address, and telephone number and the name, breed, color, age, sex, physical
location where the dog or cat is kept, and microchip and tattoo information of
each dog or cat for which application is made.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-15: RABIES VACCINATION:
   As a condition for the issuance of a City pet license for a dog or cat, all
applications for such license shall procure and deliver to the licensing
authority a certificate issued by a duly licensed veterinarian certifying the
dog or cat to be licensed has been administered an anti-rabies vaccination
sufficient to immunize said dog or cat against rabies for the entire license
period.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-16: ISSUANCE OF TAGS AND CERTIFICATES:
   A metallic tag and license certificate with corresponding number shall be
furnished by a veterinarian or other proper license authority upon payment of
the appropriate fee.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-17: OWNER MUST ATTACH LICENSE:
The licensing authority shall keep a record of the name of such owner or person
making payment of said license fee and to whom a certificate and tag shall have
been issued, and the number and date of such certificate and such tag. Such
metal tag shall be securely fixed to a collar, harness or other device to be
worn at all times by the registered dog or cat. Cats and dogs are exempt from
wearing a tag as long as the animal is in compliance with Section
4-2-5 and is microchipped with current information.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-18: TAG OR CERTIFICATE MUST BE SHOWN:
   No person shall fail or refuse to show to any Animal Welfare Officer, Code
Enforcement or Police Officer, upon request, the license certificate or tag for
any duly registered dog or cat kept or remaining with any home or upon any
enclosed premises under their immediate control. (Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-19: REMOVAL OF REGISTRATION TAGS PROHIBITED:
   Only the owner or licensing authority shall have the authority to remove or
cause the removal of the license tag or other device authorized by the
licensing authority used to identify the dog or cat owner.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-20: LOST AND DESTROYED TAGS:
   If the license tag is lost or destroyed, the owner shall have 30 days to
procure a new license tag or other identifying device authorized by and from
the licensing authority for a fee established administratively. (Ord. 1295, 2-
13-2024)
4-2-21: COUNTERFEIT AND IMITATION TAGS:
   No person shall imitate or counterfeit tags or other devices authorized by
the licensing authority prescribed by this Title, or have in his possession any
imitation or counterfeit device or tags. (Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-22: AUTHORITY TO EUTHANIZE:
   The Animal Welfare Center shall have the authority to carry out the humane
euthanasia of any animal lawfully taken into custody by the Animal Welfare
Center which is:
   A.   Affected with any dangerous, painful, incurable or communicable
disease;
   B.   Incurably crippled or suffering incurably after reasonable effort has
been made to notify the owner; or
   C.   Deemed to have dangerous or aggressive behavior.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-2-23: PENALTIES:
   Except as otherwise provided in this section, any person convicted of
violating the provisions of any section or subsection of this chapter shall be
a misdemeanor offense and subject to punishment in accordance with Title 1,
Chapter 1,
Section 8 and
9 respectively of this Code. Each day upon which a violation continues shall be
considered a separate offense.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
CHAPTER 3
ANIMALS OTHER THAN DOGS AND CATS
SECTION:
4-3-1: Keeping Of Animals Other Than Dogs And Cats
4-3-2: Killing Of Wild Birds
4-3-3: Movement Of Livestock
4-3-4: Large Reptiles Allowed
4-3-1: KEEPING OF ANIMALS OTHER THAN DOGS AND CATS:
   A.   Non-Domestic Farm Animals Prohibited; Exceptions. Except, as provided
otherwise, all animals commonly known as domesticated farm animals may be kept
and maintained in any of the City's zoning districts only as long as:
      1.   The provisions of Title 12 of this Code pertaining thereto are
complied with;
      2.   Such animals maintained in single-family, two-family or multifamily
districts are not permitted closer than:
         a.   Twenty-five feet (25') to a lot line upon which is situated an
inhabited dwelling; nor
         b.   One hundred feet (100') to any dwelling other than the owner's;
         c.   The owner or occupant of the land upon which such animals are
kept and maintained erects and maintains a suitable barrier sufficient to
ensure compliance with the above distance requirements.
   B.   Chickens; Roosters Prohibited. Except, as provided otherwise, chickens
or laying hens may be kept and maintained in the R-1 zoning district so long
as:
      1.   The provisions of Title 12 of this Code pertaining thereto are
complied with;
      2.   Such chickens or laying hens are maintained on land upon which the
owner or occupant resides;
      3.   Roosters shall not be permitted in any zoning district.
   C.   Chickens or laying hens may only be kept under the following
conditions:
      1.   No more than four (4) chickens or laying hens are allowed per R-1-
zoned parcel unless additional setback conditions can be achieved as described
in subsection A.2. of this section;
      2.   The chickens are kept within a designated chicken coop and chicken
run, unless supervised as described in subsection B.3.m. of this section;
      3.   The chicken coop and chicken run shall be located in the rear or
backyard of a residential property. No part of the coop or run shall be located
in the side or front yard;
      4.   The chicken coop and chicken run shall be attached and shall be
located no closer than five feet from any side or rear property lines and no
closer than twenty-five feet (25') from any dwelling unit other than the
owner's. Movable chicken enclosures are permitted as long as they meet the
setbacks as indicated in this section;
      5.   The minimum size for a chicken coop shall be four (4) square feet
per animal and the chicken run shall be eight square feet per animal;
      6.   During daylight hours, the chickens shall have access to a chicken
run and a chicken coop;
      7.   From dusk until dawn, chickens shall be kept within the chicken coop
as protection from predators;
      8.   Chicken coops shall be predator resistant and any open walls or
windows shall be designed to prevent access by predators;
      9.   Chicken runs shall be adequately fenced and protected from
predators;
      10.   The outside openings of any enclosure shall be screened to prevent
the spread of disease by flies and vermin;
      11.   Water shall be provided onsite and accessible to chickens at all
times;
      12.   Chickens are permitted to be outside of a run or coop during
daylight hours but must be supervised and contained inside a fenced yard at all
times; chickens that stray outside the fenced yard may be regarded as nuisance
animals under the provisions of Section 4-1-1 herein;
      13.   All chicken enclosures shall be cleaned regularly to prevent an
accumulation of food, fecal matter, or nesting material from creating a
nuisance or unsanitary condition due to odor, vermin, debris, or decay.
      14.   Electrical and heat sources shall comply with the City's building
code.
   D.   Swine prohibited. No person shall own, keep, or maintain a swine within
the City limits, except in those areas zoned A-1 or A-2 and only then when in
compliance with the limitations regarding those areas.
   E.   Exotic and Native Wildlife; Reptiles. Except as otherwise provided, no
person shall keep and maintain, or allow to be maintained any exotic or native
wildlife or dangerous or venomous reptiles.
   F.   Exceptions. Persons and entities excepted from of the requirements of
this section shall be:
      1.   Duly authorized educational institutions;
      2.   Agents or employees properly authorized by an educational
institution to keep and maintain that institution's animals in connection with
any lawful experimental or research program;
      3.   City recognized Zoological gardens;
      4.   Zoos which are supervised and publicly maintained;
      5.   Falconry facilities that have a current license issued by the U.S.
Department of the Interior, by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, or a license
issued by the Oklahoma Department of Wildlife Conservation under the rules
adopted in 50 CFR 21 of the Federal Regulations;
      6.   Jasmine Moran Children's Museum;
   G.   Transportation; Access. Anyone housing or maintaining any animal
subject to this section shall be required to ensure the animal is properly
secured during any transport, remains detained, or prohibited from unsafe
access to others;
   H.   Documentation. Anyone housing or maintaining an animal subject to this
section shall be required to provide proof of required licensing and liability
insurance to any City officer or designated authority for keeping and
displaying said animal.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-3-2: KILLING OF WILD BIRDS:
   A.   Prohibitions. No person shall trap, hunt, shoot, kill, destroy,
capture, or molest any wild bird, or rob or molest any such bird's nest.
   B.   Exceptions. Persons excepted from subsection (a) of this section are as
follows:
      1.   Those persons hunting and killing game birds as defined and
regulated by the laws, rules and regulations of the U.S. Government, the State
of Oklahoma, the City, their agencies or branches; and within those areas
authorized by the City;
      2.   City employees authorized by the Police Chief, animal control
personnel or other appropriate authority who eliminate starlings, pigeons, or
other wild birds who increase in such great numbers or are found congregating
to such an extent within the City so as may constitute or potentially
constitute a health hazard or nuisance to City residents, in accordance with
State and federal wildlife laws.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-3-3: MOVEMENT OF LIVESTOCK:
   No person shall allow any livestock to be at-large, picketed, staked,
herded, or driven upon any of the alleys, streets, or public ground within the
City.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-3-4: LARGE REPTILES ALLOWED:
   No person shall knowingly and intentionally harbor, possess or keep large
reptiles, such as snakes, lizards, or tortoises that are capable of exceeding
twenty-five pounds (25 lbs.) at an adult age on any lot, premises or in any
structure, without first completing registration with the Animal Control
authorities so that a confidential list of locations may be recorded for public
safety needs. Contents of this list shall not be available for public review or
release without court order. For the purpose of this section, these reptiles
may include but are not limited to, the Burmese Python, African Rock Python,
Reticulated Python, Green Anaconda, Yellow Anaconda, Komodo Dragon, and African
Spurred-Thigh Tortoise. Nothing within this section shall allow for animals
prohibited by this Code.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
CHAPTER 4
DANGEROUS ANIMALS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Dangerous Animals Prohibited
4-4-2: Animals Classified By Other Governmental Entities
4-4-3: Animal Bite
4-4-4: Investigation Authority And Dangerous Animal Designation
4-4-5: Confinement/Impoundment
4-4-6: Authority To Seize A Dangerous Animal
4-4-7: Hearing And Adjudication
4-4-8: Dangerous Animal Permit Required
4-4-9: Exceptions To Dangerous Animal Classification
4-4-10: Exception Of Certain Facilities
4-4-1: DANGEROUS ANIMALS PROHIBITED:
   It shall be unlawful for any person to own, harbor, possess or keep within
City limits any dangerous animal, as defined in Section
4-1-1 of this Title, except in compliance with the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-4-2: ANIMALS CLASSIFIED BY OTHER GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES:
   It shall be unlawful for any person to own, harbor, possess, keep or
maintain an animal which another governmental entity has determined to be
dangerous, except in compliance with the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-4-3: ANIMAL BITE:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for the owner, harborer, possessor, or keeper of
an animal to negligently allow or maintain any animal where it could bite a
person unless the animal has been subjected to provocation, or unless the
victim has been trespassing, as defined in Section
10-2-13 of this Code.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for the owner, harborer, possessor, or keeper of
an animal to negligently allow or maintain any animal to bite, attack or kill
another animal unless the animal has been subjected to provocation or attack by
another animal, as defined in Section
4-1-1 of this Title.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for the owner, harborer, possessor, or keeper of
any animal which has the potential to transmit rabies, or for the victim, if
the victim is reasonably physically able, to fail to report an animal bite to
the Animal Welfare Center or 911 as soon as possible. Common animals that may
carry rabies include dogs, cats, bats, raccoons, ferrets, cattle, foxes,
wolves, coyotes, monkeys, and skunks.
   D.   It shall be unlawful for any person knowing the location of such an
animal to fail to inform the Animal Welfare Center of where the animal is
located if the owner, harborer, possessor, or keeper has given the animal away
or caused in any way the animal to be taken from his premises.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-4-4: INVESTIGATION AUTHORITY AND DANGEROUS ANIMAL DESIGNATION:
The Chief of Police, Animal Welfare Supervisor or authorized designee shall
investigate any incident appearing to involve a dangerous animal, or any
citizen compliant of a dangerous animal, or any impoundment of an animal
believed to be a dangerous animal. If the incident or impoundment meets the
criteria for classification of an animal as dangerous as defined in Section
4-1-1 of this Title, a citation shall be issued. Upon issuance of a citation,
any animal declared to be a dangerous animal not already impounded shall be
impounded and confined as set forth in this Title.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-4-5: CONFINEMENT/IMPOUNDMENT:
An animal that is impounded at the time of an incident or after an
investigation that resulted in the owner being charged with harboring or
possessing a dangerous animal shall be confined pending the disposition of the
animal. Such confinement shall be at the owner's expenses. Provided, however,
the animal may be confined in a licensed veterinary clinic, other licensed
facility, or confined at the home of the owner in accordance with Section
4-1-1 of this Title, at the discretion of the Animal Welfare Supervisor or
authorized authority.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-4-6: AUTHORITY TO SEIZE A DANGEROUS ANIMAL:
In addition to any other authority or procedure authorized by this Title or by
any other law to seize an animal, any law enforcement officer or Animal Welfare
Officer shall have the authority to immediately seize any animal when said
authority has cause to believe that an animal is dangerous or poses a serious
threat to public safety under the totality of the circumstances.
It shall be unlawful for any person owning, keeping, possessing or otherwise
maintaining an animal declared to be a dangerous animal to refuse to
immediately surrender the animal for confinement as outlined in Section
4-4-5 of this Title.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-4-7: HEARING AND ADJUDICATION:
If, after a citation is issued alleging an animal as a dangerous animal, as set
forth in Section
4-4-1 of this Title, the owner does not appear at the time for appearance, the
animal shall be deemed abandoned and subject to disposition pursuant to Section
4-2-5 herein. The hearing shall be set within ten (10) days of issuance of a
citation.
The Municipal Court Judge, upon a finding that the animal is a dangerous
animal, may cause the following:
   A.   Allow the animal to remain within the City limits under restrictions as
designated in this chapter;
   B.   Order the removal of the animal from the City limits; or
   C.   Order the destruction of the animal.
   Upon a second conviction, the Judge shall order the destruction of the
animal.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-4-8: DANGEROUS ANIMAL PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A dangerous animal may be kept within the City limits as long as the owner
or custodian complies with the requirements and conditions set forth below, as
well as any special conditions imposed by any animal control authority to
ensure the safety of the general public, to wit:
   A.   Permit. The owner shall acquire a dangerous animal permit for
possession of a dangerous animal within ten (10) days of the animal being
adjudicated as a dangerous animal. Animal control authorities shall inspect the
premises before any permit is issued. Any permit fee imposed shall be in
addition to all other required fees.
   B.   Confinement. All dangerous animals shall be securely confined (1)
indoors, or (2) in an enclosed or locked pen or physical structure upon the
premises of the owner. The pen or physical structure must meet the minimum
space requirements of at least one hundred fifty (150) square feet and must
have secure sides and a secure top attached to the sides. If no bottom is
secured to the side, the sides must be embedded into the ground no less than
two feet (2'). The pen or physical structure must be capable of preventing the
entry of the general public, including children, and must be capable of
preventing the escape or release of the animal. Electronic containment devices
shall not be used to confine dangerous animal.
   C.   Leash and muzzle. The owner of a dangerous animal shall not allow the
animal to go outside of its kennel, pen or physical structure unless the animal
is muzzled, restrained by a leash sufficient to control the animal, and under
the physical control of an adult. The muzzle must not cause injury to the
animal or interfere with its vision or respiration but must prevent the animal
from biting any human or animal. A muzzle is not required if the animal is in
the owner's yard (front and/or back) enclosed by a fence that is capable of
preventing uninvited entry by other animals or people or is restrained by means
of a leash held by an adult.
   D.   Signs. The owner of a dangerous animal shall provide public notice of
the animal's presence on the premises by displaying a warning sign. The sign
shall be at least eight inches (8") by ten inches (10") in size, placed in a
prominent place on the owner's property, clearly visible from the public
highway or street. Similar signs shall be posted on the animal's kennel, pen or
enclosed structure.
   E.   Vaccinations and licenses. The owner of a dangerous animal shall file
proof to ensure that the animal remains current on any vaccinations or licenses
required by this Title or any other applicable laws or regulations.
   F.   Photographic identification. Within ten (10) days of the declaration of
an animal as dangerous, the owner or custodian shall provide animal control
authorities with two (2), four inches (4") by six inches (6") digital-quality
color photographs of such animal, clearly showing the color and approximate
size of the animal, or shall make the animal available for photographing by the
Animal Welfare Center or other appropriate Animal Control authorities.
   G.   Microchipping of animal. Upon conviction of a violation of this
section, the Judge of the Municipal Court shall order the owner, possessor,
harborer or keeper of such animal to have an identification microchip implanted
in such animal by a licensed veterinarian no later than fifteen (15) calendar
days after the conviction at the owner's expense. The owner, possessor,
harborer, or keeper shall file proof of microchipping, acceptable to the animal
control authorities no later than twenty (20) calendar days after conviction.
Failure of the owner, harborer, possessor or keeper of such animal to have the
microchip implanted in the animal or to file acceptable proof of microchipping,
within twenty (20) days after conviction, shall be punished as contempt of
court. Upon the commencement of contempt proceedings against the owner,
harborer, possessor or keeper of such animal, the Municipal Court shall issue
an ex parte order, at the owner's expense, directing animal control authorities
to seize the animal, which shall be held and shall not be released until the
conclusion of the contempt proceedings.
   H.   Liability Insurance. The owner must procure liability insurance
covering any injury or illness to persons or other animals caused by said
dangerous animal in the owner's care, custody or possession in the minimum
amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) at the owner's expense and
provide documentation thereof to animal control authorities.
   I.   Mandatory Notification. The owner or custodian of a dangerous animal
shall notify the animal control authorities immediately if the animal is
unconfined; at large; or has attacked a person or other animal.
   J.   Change of ownership. If the owner of a dangerous animal sells, gives
away, or otherwise transfers custody of the animal, the owner shall on the next
business day provide animal control authorities with written documentation
containing the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner or
custodian. The previous owner shall upon transferring ownership or custody
notify the new owner of the animal's designation as a dangerous animal. This
notice shall be in writing and a copy shall be provided to animal control
authorities. Upon being notified that a dangerous animal has been removed to
another jurisdiction, the animal control authorities are authorized, but not
required, to notify the appropriate governmental department in the jurisdiction
where the dangerous animal has been transferred and notify them that the animal
has been previously declared dangerous.
   K.   Civil and Criminal Penalties. It shall be unlawful for the owner or
custodian of a dangerous animal to fail to comply with the requirements and
conditions set forth in this section. Any animal found to be kept in violation
of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished in accordance
with Section
1-1-8 and
1-1-9 of this Code. In addition, the animal at issue may be subject to seizure
and impoundment at the owner's expense and result in the revocation of the
dangerous animal permit for such animal. In the event of permit revocation, the
owner or custodian shall remove such animal from the City limits within twenty-
four (24) hours of receipt of the notice of revocation, or the animal shall be
humanely euthanized without further notice to the owner.
   L.   Exception: Dogs that are used regularly for law enforcement purposes
shall not be subject to this section but shall be confined and maintained in
accordance with the law enforcement agency's policy.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-4-9: EXCEPTIONS TO DANGEROUS ANIMAL CLASSIFICATION:
   A.   Injury to Animals. No animal, whether or not it was confined on its
owner's property, shall be classified as a dangerous animal because of injuries
or death it has inflicted upon another domestic animal that, at the time, was
attacking the animal.
   B.   Injury to Persons. It is a defense to prosecution under Section
4-4-4 herein that the biting, attacking or death was sustained by a person who:
      1.   At the time was committing or attempting to commit a willful
trespass or other tort upon the property occupied by the owner of the animal;
      2.   Was attempting to or was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the
animal or has, in the past, been observed or reported to have tormented,
abused, or assaulted the animal; or
      3.   Was committing or attempting to commit a crime.
   C.   No Presumption of Dangerous Disposition. An animal which approaches a
person in an apparent attitude of attack, or which attacks or bites a person
upon command of the person in charge of the animal at the time of the incident
shall not, by reason of such incident, be automatically deemed to be in
violation of Section
4-4-4 herein. However, nothing shall limit the ability of animal control
authorities from all considering said circumstances in conjunction with other
facts in making said determination.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-4-10: EXCEPTION OF CERTAIN FACILITIES:
   The provisions of this article shall not apply to any veterinary hospital or
zoo or other licensed facility where such animals are adequately cared for with
due regard for public health and safety.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
CHAPTER 5
DOGS AND CATS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Abandonment Of Cats And Dogs
4-5-2: Tethering
4-5-3: Confinement Of Dogs And Cats
4-5-4: Prohibition Of Dogs And Cats In Certain Areas
4-5-5: Vaccination Of Dogs And Cats
4-5-6: Number Of Dogs And/Or Cats Allowed
4-5-7: Sale Of Dogs Or Cats
4-5-8: Interference With Enforcement
4-5-9: Permitting Dogs Or Cats To Deposit Solid Waste Material On Places Open
To The Public Or On Certain Private Property Prohibited
4-5-1: ABANDONMENT OF CATS AND DOGS:
   No person shall abandon or desert their dog or cat or permit such animal to
become a stray. Any dog or cat found at-large not wearing any tag indicating
proof of current vaccination against rabies, or that the owner is a City
resident, shall be presumed abandoned, and will be impounded by the City. The
provisions of Section
4-2-6 with regard to owners shall also apply to abandoned animals.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-5-2: TETHERING:
   A.   Tethering Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog or
cat to keep or maintain the animal on a tie-out, tether, picket, or similar
device consisting of a rope, cable, or other type of tether for any duration
unless continually supervised by its owner or other adult responsible for the
animal at the time. Exemptions in certain circumstances may be granted by
appropriate animal control authorities or law enforcement officer.
   B.   Conditions for Exemption. Any person who receives an exemption shall
ensure that the animal will not be on the tie-out, tether, picket, or similar
device for any duration under conditions which may reasonably threaten the
health or well-being of the animal. The owner of a dog or cat maintained on a
tether of any type shall properly fit the animal with a harness or collar to
which the tether shall be attached. The tether shall be of adequate length to
allow reasonable exercise, access to water, shelter, and shall not be subject
to entanglement with other objects in any manner that may cause the animal any
injury or clear discomfort or be of a weight disproportionate to the size of
the animal so tethered as to unduly burden the animal. Tethering dogs or cats
using chains or prong collars is prohibited. Tethering of an unsupervised dog
or cat is prohibited when the outside air temperature is not between thirty-
five and eighty-five degrees Fahrenheit (35°F - 85°F).
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-5-3: CONFINEMENT OF DOGS AND CATS:
   No person shall knowingly or unknowingly permit his or her dog to be at-
large anywhere within the City limits; and such dogs found at-large may be
impounded and/or the owner cited by the City.
   No person shall knowingly or unknowingly permit his or her cat to be at-
large unless the cat is altered, current on its vaccinations, as required in
this chapter, has a valid issued pet license, and has either a collar with a
valid City pet license attached or has a registered microchip containing
accurate and current information for the owner, notwithstanding that the cat
could still be determined to be a nuisance animal by its actions as defined in
Sections
4-1-1 and
4-5-9 of this code.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-5-4: PROHIBITION OF DOGS AND CATS IN CERTAIN AREAS:
Regulations pertaining to the prohibition and exceptions of live animals on the
premises of a food establishment, as established in Oklahoma Administrative
Code, 310:257-11-54 (Prohibiting Animals), shall be enforceable as if listed
entirely in this section.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-5-5: VACCINATION OF DOGS AND CATS:
   No person shall keep, harbor, or maintain any dog or cat over four months
old within the City without having first had that animal vaccinated against
rabies. Said vaccination shall be current as prescribed by the State Department
of Health Zoonotic Disease Control Rules, Title 310, Chapter 599.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-5-6: NUMBER OF DOGS AND/OR CATS ALLOWED:
   A.   Unaltered Animals. No person shall harbor or keep any dogs or cats if
any are unaltered that exceed the following:
      1.   More than two (2) dogs, more than six (6) months of age, may be kept
on any lot, premises or in any structure, or any combination thereof, without a
commercial, rescue, or private kennel license. No more than one litter of
puppies may be kept on any lot or premises or kept in any structure, without a
kennel license; or
      2.   More than three (3) domesticated cats, more than six (6) months of
age, may be kept on any lot, premises, or in any structure, or any combination
thereof, without a commercial, rescue, or private kennel license. Not more than
one litter of kittens may be kept on any lot or premises or kept in any
structure, without a kennel license.
   B.   Altered Animals. No person shall harbor, possess or keep dogs or cats
unless all have been altered that exceed the following:
      1.   More than four (4) dogs over the age of six (6) months of age on any
lot or premises or kept in any structure, or any combination thereof, without a
commercial, rescue, or private kennel license; or
      2.   More than six (6) cats over the age of six (6) months of age on any
lot or premises or kept in any structure, or any combination thereof, without a
commercial, rescue, or private kennel license.
   C.   Exceptions. Households functioning as a foster home for an Animal
Welfare Group registered with the City shall be granted an over limit exception
for up to six (6) months per dog or cat, not to exceed three (3) additional
dogs and/or five (5) additional cats beyond the number establishing kennel
license requirements effective upon filing written notification to the Animal
Welfare Center.
      If a complaint is made against a foster home, the owner and Animal
Welfare Group will be subject to a review as allowed for kennel licensed
location to review the circumstances and to provide for approval or denial of a
continued over limit exception at that location.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-5-7: SALE OF DOGS OR CATS:
   It shall be unlawful for any person to offer any animal for sale, or to
trade, exchange, barter or give away or to accept any animal on any property
not owned or rented by the seller or buyer or on any public curbsides,
roadsides, alleyways, streets, parks, or parking lots unless specifically
permitted by the City to do so.
   Animal Welfare Groups registered with and approved by the City are exempt
from the above section when conducting adoption events on property not owned by
the group with authorization from the property owner.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-5-8: INTERFERENCE WITH ENFORCEMENT:
   No person shall interfere with, hinder, or molest an Animal Welfare Officer
or other employee of the Animal Welfare Center in the performance of any duty
of such agent, or seek to release any dog or cat in the custody of the Animal
Welfare Officer or Animal Welfare Center except as herein provided.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-5-9:    PERMITTING DOGS OR CATS TO DEPOSIT SOLID WASTE MATERIAL ON PLACES
OPEN TO THE PUBLIC OR ON CERTAIN PRIVATE PROPERTY PROHIBITED:
   It shall be unlawful for the owner, keeper, or person having control of any
dog or cat to permit such dog or cat to defecate upon any sidewalk, public
park, street, alley, or other place open to the public, or on private property
without the permission of the owner thereof. In the event that the owner,
keeper, or person having control of any animal is unable to prevent the deposit
of fecal material in violation of this section, it shall be the duty of such
person to properly collect and dispose of such waste material within a
reasonable time and before leaving the immediate area.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
CHAPTER 6
MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
SECTION:
4-6-1: Cruelty To Animals
4-6-2: Transportation Of Animals In Open Areas Of Motor Vehicles
4-6-3: Animals Considered Nuisances
4-6-4:    Clean Enclosures And Pens Required
4-6-5:    Reporting Of Found Animals
4-6-1: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
   A.   No person shall maliciously:
      1.   Torture, cruelly beat, injure, maim, mutilate, or unjustly destroy
or kill any animal;
      2.   Deprive any animal in subjugation or captivity of food generally
accepted as being nutritious, potable drinking water, or adequate shelter;
      3.   Administer any poison or noxious drug or substance to any animal;
      4.   Expose any drug or substance with the intent that the same shall be
taken by an animal, whether such animal be the property of that owner or
another person;
      5.   Cause any other person to do any of the above items;
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to leave any animal in any standing
or parked vehicle, box, container or other situation without providing for
adequate ventilation nor shall a person allow an animal to be exposed to
extreme temperature while confined in a vehicle, box, container or other
situation which would likely cause distress, harm or death to the animal;
   C.   It shall be unlawful to intentionally torment, harass, throw objects
at, verbally or physically confront any animal, whether confined or unconfined,
in a manner to cause unjustified agitation or injury to the animal;
   D.   No person shall cause an animal to be overloaded or forced to work in a
manner unsuitable to its species, breed, condition or health so as to cause
injury to the animal;
   E.   No person shall fail to provide or deprive any animal in their
possession, care, or control reasonable medical or necessary veterinary care if
the animal is sick, diseased, and/or injured;
   F.   It shall be unlawful to participate in, assist with, sell, transport or
otherwise allow any animal to be dyed, colored, or otherwise similarly altered
for the purposes as a promotional item, prize, or giveaway. This prohibition
shall in no way limit the actions of a commercial or private groomer, medical
care provider, or owner preparing an animal for a commonly recognized and
accepted competition or show event as long as the action is performed in a safe
and humane way that does not result in discomfort or injury to the animal;
   G.   It shall be unlawful to participate in, assist with, sell, transport or
otherwise allow any animal to be provided to another person as a promotional
item, or prize to be given away at any event, festival, carnival, or parade.
   H.   Authority to Confiscate Abused or Neglected Animals. Animal Welfare,
Police, or Fire Department Officials are hereby authorized to remove, impound
or take possession of any animal which has been treated in violation of
subsection (a) of this section.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-6-2: TRANSPORTATION OF ANIMALS IN OPEN AREAS OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
   It is unlawful on any roadway or highway within the City for the operator of
any open motor vehicle, including, but not limited to, pickup trucks and
flatbed trucks without a topper or any attached accessory such as an open
trailer, to transport an animal in the open area where the animal could
unintentionally fall, jump or be thrown from the vehicle and be injured or
killed.
   The animal shall be transported in the following manner:
   A.   Safely tethered where it cannot fall, jump or be thrown out of the open
area of the vehicle and the animal is safe from becoming tangled and causing
the animal to become chocked or injured; or
   B.   Enclosed in a carrier that is of adequate size and properly ventilated,
or in an approved transportation carrier designed for animals, and the
container is safely secured or attached to the vehicle.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-6-3: ANIMALS CONSIDERED NUISANCES:
   A.   No person shall own, keep, possess, or harbor any animal that is a
nuisance unless the animal is confined at the residence of the owner as
described in Section
4-1-1 herein or if off the premises outside the residence of the owner the
animal is at heel as described in said provision.
   B.   The Municipal Court Judge, upon a finding that the animal is a nuisance
animal, may order that the animal be confined on the premises of the owner, as
well as other measures as may be required to preserve the public peace and
welfare.
   C.   Subsequent violations. If there are three (3) convictions, pleas of
guilty or nolo contendere of violations of this section or Section
4-5-3 against the same animal within a twelve (12)-month period, then such
animal shall be ordered removed from the City limits or destroyed, at the
owner's option, within ten days of the order.
   D.   Noncompliance shall be a violation punishable as listed in Section
4-2-23 of this Title.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-6-4: CLEAN ENCLOSURES AND PENS REQUIRED:
   All pens or enclosures for animals shall be maintained in a clean condition
and be free of filth at all times. All manure shall be cleaned daily from the
pens, and, if kept in a manure pile, such shall be removed at least twice
weekly. Each pen and enclosure shall be sprayed with a suitable residual spray
as often as is necessary to control flies, insects, and noxious odors.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
4-6-5: REPORTING OF FOUND ANIMALS:
   Any person who takes possession of, keeps or harbors an animal that
reasonably appears to be at-large or stray shall make notification to the
animal shelter within seventy-two (72) hours. Such notification shall include a
complete and accurate description of the animal, when and where it was located,
where it is being housed, and contact information for the reporting person. The
person reporting the animal shall additionally ensure the animal is scanned for
a microchip or inspected for identifying markings by an animal shelter, medical
provider, or rescue.
(Ord. 1295, 2-13-2024)
TITLE 5
BUILDING REGULATIONS AND CODES
CHAPTER 1
BUILDING CODE
SECTION:
5-1-1: Building Code Adopted; Revisions
5-1-2: Building And House Numbers
5-1-3: Violation; Penalty
5-1-4: Hotel And Motel Contractors
5-1-1: BUILDING CODE ADOPTED; REVISIONS:
   A.   That a certain document, two (2) copies of which are on file in the
office of the City Clerk of City of Seminole, being marked and designated as
the International Building Code, 2021 Edition, including all Appendix Chapters
as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the
Building Code of the City of Seminole, in the State of Oklahoma for regulating
and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and
structures; by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities
and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures
are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use; and the condemnation of
buildings and structures unfit for human occupancy and use and the demolition
of such structures as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits
and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations,
provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Building Code on file in
the office of the City of Seminole are hereby referred to , adopted and made a
part thereof, as if filly set out in this legislation, with the additions,
insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in Section 2 of this
ordinance.
   B.   The Following sections are hereby revised:
   Section 101.1. City of Seminole Section 1612.3. City of Seminole Section
1612.3. November 30, 2022.
   Section 1507.8, Wood Shingles. The installation of wood shingles in new
construction is prohibited unless the distance to adjacent structures is a
minimum of 30 feet. The installation of wood shingles shall comply with the
provisions of this section and table 1507.8.
   Section 1507.9, Wood Shakes. The installation of wood shakes in new
construction is prohibited unless the distance to adjacent structures is a
minimum of 30 feet. The installation of wood shakes shall comply with the
provisions of this section and table 1507.8.
   Section 1512, Reroofing, is amended by adding the following sections:
   Section 1512.1.1: Wood shingles and shakes shall not be permitted as roof
coverings on structures within the city. Existing wood shingle roofs may be
repaired using wood shingles when the area to be repaired is less than 25
percent of the existing total roof area. Exception: Wood shingles are allowed
when there is a 30-foot distance from adjacent structures.
   1512.1.2: Permit Requirements: The building official shall issue permits for
the replacement of all roofs for structures located within the city limits.
   C.   Exemptions to code:
      1.   The following shall be exempt from 2021 ICC Residential Building
Code R313, which requires sprinkler systems in all new homes:
         a.   Single family homes under four thousand five hundred (4,500)
square feet of living space;
         b.   Two-family homes with a two (2)-hour firewall separating dwelling
units;
         c.   Townhomes with more than two (2) ground level egress points with
dwelling units separated by two (2)-hour firewalls.
(Ord. 1181, 9-8-2015; amd. Ord. 1274, 11-8-2022; Ord. 1291, 8-8-2023)
5-1-2: BUILDING AND HOUSE NUMBERS:
   All buildings and houses fronting on a public street are required to attach
to, or in front of, the building or house the correct number, as assigned by
the Building Department, the minimum size being three inches (3") in height and
visible from the street. (Ord. 1181, 9-8-2015)
5-1-3: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   Any person found violating any provision of this title or the codes adopted
shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 of this Code.
(Ord. 1181, 9-8-2015)
5-1-4: HOTEL AND MOTEL CONTRACTORS:
   A.   License Required: All general and subcontractors obtaining a permit for
the construction of hotel or motel space shall be licensed with the Office of
Community Development until June 1, 2023. General contractors and sub-
contractors must certify that all contractors will be licensed by the State of
Oklahoma and be in compliance with the Construction Industries Board.
   B.   License Required, Commercial: A commercial license shall be issued upon
verification of a current and valid registration through the Oklahoma
Construction Industries Board, unless exempt by said board regulations. A
commercial license shall be valid for construction of hotel or motel units
within the boundaries of the City of Seminole.
   C.   License Term And Fee:
      1.   Licenses shall be valid for up to one year and shall expire on May
31 of each year. The annual fee is as follows:
 
Hotel units $2,000.00 per unit
Motel units 1,000.00 per unit
 
   D.   License Suspension Or Revocation: The Director of Community Development
and/or the building inspector shall have the authority to suspend or revoke any
license for continuous violations of this title or for good cause shown. When
the revocation of any such license is to be considered, the contractor shall
have at least three (3) days' notice in writing of the time and place of a
revocation hearing, together with a statement of the grounds upon which it is
proposed to revoke such license.
   E.   Permits For The Construction Of A Hotel/Motel: A commercial building
permit shall be issued only to a licensed hotel/motel contractor as required by
this section.
   F.   Violation; Penalty: Any person found violating this provision of this
chapter, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with sections 1-1-
8 and
1-1-9 of this Code. (Ord. 1217, 4-10-2018)
CHAPTER 2
PLUMBING CODE 1
SECTION:
5-2-1: Plumbing Code Adopted; Revisions
5-2-2: Permit And Fees
5-2-3: Licensing And Bonding Of Plumbers
5-2-4: Plumbing And Gas Contractors
 
Notes
1 1. See section 5-1-3 of this title for penalty provisions.
5-2-1: PLUMBING CODE ADOPTED; REVISIONS:
   A.   That a certain document, two (2) copies of which are on file in the
office the City Clerk of the City of Seminole, being marked and designated as
the International Plumbing Code, 2021 Edition, including all Appendix Chapters,
as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the
Plumbing Code of the City of Seminole, in the State of Oklahoma regulating and
governing the design, construction, quality of materials, erection,
installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition
to, use or maintenance of plumbing systems as herein provided; providing for
the issuance of permits and collection of fee therefor; and each and all of the
regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Plumbing Code
on file in the office of the City of Seminole are hereby referred to, adopted,
and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this legislation, with the
additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection
B. of this section.
   B.   The following sections are hereby revised:
   Section 101.1. City of Seminole.
   Section 106.6.2 Omit Schedule.
   Section106.6.3 Remove.
   Section 108.4. change to Section 115.4.
   Section 108.5. Remove.
   Section 109, Means of Appeal: Omit entire section and replace with Section
113.
   Section 715.1, change to Section 714.1, Sewage Backflow, and amend as
follows:
      A backwater valve shall be installed on all building sewers that connect
to the public sewer system. This shall be required for all new construction and
on existing buildings as sewer lines are repaired or replaced.
   Section 715.5, change to 714.3, Location, and amend to read as follows:
