                                     doorways, open or closed windows,
                                     stairways, or the like. The provisions
                                     of this section shall apply to such
                                     indoor workplace at any given time,
                                     whether or not work is being performed.
                                     All buildings, indoor areas, and outdoor
                                     areas, including but not limited to
                                     recreational areas, and other property,
MUNICIPAL PROPERTY:                  or portions thereof, owned or operated
                                     by the city, including but not limited
                                     to vehicles and equipment owned by the
                                     municipality.
                                     Any covered area, partially covered area
OUTDOOR AREA:                        or area open to the sky that is on a
                                     property owned by the city.
                                     Any enclosed indoor area where
                                     individuals other than employees are
PUBLIC PLACE:                        invited or permitted; the term is
                                     synonymous with the phrase "any indoor
                                     place used by or open to the public".
                                     Any area that is owned, controlled or
                                     used by the city of Seminole and open to
                                     the general public for recreational
                                     purposes, regardless of any fee or age
                                     requirement. The term "recreational
RECREATIONAL AREA:                   area" includes, but is not limited to,
                                     parks, picnic areas, playgrounds, sports
                                     fields, golf courses, walking paths,
                                     gardens, hiking trails, bike paths,
                                     riding trails, swimming pools, roller
                                     and ice skating rinks, beaches
                                     surrounding lakes, and skateboard parks.
RESTAURANT:                          Any eating establishment regardless of
                                     seating capacity.
                                     The carrying by a person of a lighted
SMOKING:                             cigar, cigarette, pipe or other lighted
                                     smoking device.
                                     An establishment that derives more than
                                     sixty percent (60%) of its gross
                                     receipts, subject to verification by
                                     competent authority, from the sale of
                                     alcoholic beverages and low point beer
                                     and no person under twenty one (21)
STAND ALONE BAR, STAND ALONE TAVERN, years of age is admitted, except for
AND CIGAR BAR:                       members of a musical band employed or
                                     hired as provided in 37 Oklahoma
                                     Statutes section 537, subsection B,
                                     paragraph 2 and that is not located
                                     within, and does not share any common
                                     entryway or common indoor area with, any
                                     other enclosed indoor workplace,
                                     including a restaurant.
                                     Any substance containing tobacco leaf,
                                     including, but not limited to,
                                     cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, hookah
                                     tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco, dipping
                                     tobacco, snus, bidis, or any other
                                     preparation of tobacco; and any product
                                     or formulation of matter containing
                                     biologically active amounts of nicotine
TOBACCO PRODUCT:                     that is manufactured, sold, offered for
                                     sale, or otherwise distributed with the
                                     expectation that the product or matter
                                     will be introduced into the human body.
                                     "Tobacco product" does not include any
                                     cessation product specifically approved
                                     by the United States food and drug
                                     administration for use in treating
                                     nicotine or tobacco dependence.
                                     Any noncombustible product, that may or
                                     may not contain nicotine, that employs a
                                     mechanical heating element, battery,
                                     electronic circuit, or other mechanism,
                                     regardless of shape or size, that can be
                                     used to produce a vapor in a solution or
                                     other form. Vapor Product shall include
                                     any vapor cartridge or other container
                                     with or without nicotine or other form
VAPOR PRODUCT:                       that is intended to be used with an
                                     electronic cigarette, electronic cigar,
                                     electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe,
                                     or similar product or device and any
                                     vapor cartridge or other container of a
                                     solution, that may or may not contain
                                     nicotine, that is intended to be used
                                     with or in an electronic cigarette,
                                     electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo,
                                     electronic device.
 
   C.   Possession Of Lighted Tobacco Products, Smokeless Tobacco, Chewing
Tobacco/Snuff And Vapor Product In Certain Places Prohibited:
      1.   Nuisance: The possession of lighted tobacco in any form is a public
nuisance and dangerous to public health and is hereby prohibited when such
possession is in any indoor place used by or open to the public, public
transportation, or any indoor workplace except where specifically allowed by
law.
      2.   City Property Tobacco Free: All buildings and other properties,
including indoor and outdoor areas, owned or operated by the city of Seminole,
shall be entirely tobacco free to include all forms of tobacco products
including vapor products.
      3.   Recreational Areas: All indoor and outdoor recreational areas owned
or operated by the city shall be entirely tobacco free to include all forms of
tobacco products including vapor products.
      4.   Hospitals, Clinics And Medical Facilities: All hospitals, clinics,
medical facilities and other places where persons are treated or provided
services for illness, disease or injury shall be designated as nonsmoking. In
addition to buildings, the owner, operator or administrator of said facilities
may designate all or part of outdoor property as nonsmoking. Nothing shall
prohibit the owner, operator or administrator of said facilities to designate
an outside smoking area provided said area does not jeopardize the health,
safety and welfare of the patients or clientele.
   D.   Exemptions: The restrictions provided in subsection C. of this section
shall not apply to the following:
      1.   Stand alone bars, stand alone taverns and cigar bars;
      2.   The room or rooms where licensed charitable bingo games are being
operated, but only during the hours of operation of such games;
      3.   Up to twenty five percent (25%) of the guestrooms at a hotel or
other lodging establishment;
      4.   Retail tobacco stores predominantly engaged in the sale of tobacco
products and accessories and in which the sale of other products is merely
incidental and in which no food or beverage is sold or served for consumption
on the premises;
      5.   Workplaces where only the owner or operator of the workplace, or the
immediate family of the owner or operator, performs any work in the workplace,
and the workplace has only incidental public access. "Incidental public access"
means that a place of business has only an occasional person, who is not an
employee, present at the business to transact business or make a delivery. It
does not include businesses that depend on walk-in customers for any part of
their business;
      6.   Workplaces occupied exclusively by one or more smokers, if the
workplace has only incidental public access;
      7.   Private offices occupied exclusively by one or more smokers;
      8.   Private residences and workplaces within private residences, except
that smoking shall not be allowed inside any private residence that is used as
a licensed childcare facility during hours of operation;
      9.   Medical research or treatment centers, if smoking is integral to the
research or treatment;
      10.   A facility operated by a post or organization of past or present
members of the armed forces of the United States which is exempt from taxation
pursuant to section 501(c)(8), 501(c)(10) or 501(c)(19) of the internal revenue
code, 26 USC section 501(c)(8), 501(c)(10) or 501(c)(19), when such facility is
utilized exclusively by its members and their families and for the conduct of
post or organization nonprofit operations except during an event or activity
which is open to the public; and
      11.   Any outdoor seating area of a restaurant; provided, smoking shall
not be allowed within fifteen feet (15') of any exterior public doorway or any
air intake of a restaurant.
   E.   Designated Smoking Rooms And Areas:
      1.   An employer not otherwise restricted from doing so under this
section may elect to provide smoking rooms where no work is performed except
for cleaning and maintenance during the time the room is not in use for
smoking, provided each smoking room is fully enclosed and exhausted directly to
the outside in such a manner that no smoke can drift or circulate into a
nonsmoking area. No exhaust from a smoking room shall be located within fifteen
feet (15') of any entrance, exit or air intake.
      2.   If smoking is to be permitted in any space exempted in subsection D.
of this section or in a smoking room pursuant to subsection E.1. of this
section, such smoking space must either occupy the entire enclosed indoor space
or, if it shares the enclosed space with any nonsmoking areas, the smoking
space shall be fully enclosed, exhausted directly to the outside with no air
from the smoking space circulated to any nonsmoking area, and under negative
air pressure so that no smoke can drift or circulate into a nonsmoking area
when a door to an adjacent nonsmoking area is opened. Air from a smoking room
shall not be exhausted within fifteen feet (15') of any entrance, exit or air
intake. Any employer may choose a more restrictive smoking policy, including
being totally smoke free.
      3.   A nursing facility licensed pursuant to the nursing home care act
may designate smoking rooms for residents and their guests. Such rooms shall be
fully enclosed, directly exhausted to the outside, and shall be under negative
air pressure so that no smoke can escape when a door is opened and no air is
recirculated to nonsmoking areas of the building.
      4.   Restaurants shall be totally nonsmoking or may provide nonsmoking
areas and designated smoking rooms. Food and beverage may be served in such
designated smoking rooms which shall be in a location which is fully enclosed,
directly exhausted to the outside, under negative air pressure so smoke cannot
escape when a door is opened, and no air is recirculated to nonsmoking areas of
the building. No exhaust from such room shall be located within twenty five
feet (25') of any entrance, exit or air intake. Such room shall be subject to
verification for compliance with the provisions of this subsection by the state
department of health.
   F.   Posting:
      1.   The person who owns or operates a place where smoking or tobacco use
is prohibited by law shall be responsible for posting a sign or decal, at least
four inches by two inches (4" x 2") in size, at each entrance to the building
indicating that the place is smoke free or tobacco free.
      2.   Responsibility for posting signs or decals shall be as follows:
         a.   In privately owned facilities, the owner or lessee, if a lessee
is in possession of the facilities, shall be responsible;
         b.   In corporately owned facilities, the manager and/or supervisor of
the facility involved shall be responsible; and
         c.   In publicly owned facilities, the manager and/or supervisor of
the facility shall be responsible.
   G.   Violation And Penalty: Any person who knowingly violates this section
is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a
fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one hundred dollars
($100.00).
   H.   Enforcement:
      1.   The state or local governmental agency or the person who owns or
operates a public place shall, at a minimum, do the following in order to
prevent smoking in public places:
         a.   Post signs at entrances to places where smoking is prohibited
which state that tobacco use is prohibited; and
         b.   Ask tobacco users to refrain from using any form of tobacco
products, including vapor products, upon observation of anyone violating the
provisions of this act.
      2.   Enforcement of this chapter shall be the responsibility of the
Office of Community Development. In addition, any peace officer or code
enforcement official may enforce this chapter.
   I.   Statutory Construction And Severability: It is the intent of the City
of Seminole to supplement applicable state and federal law and not to duplicate
or contradict such law. The provisions of this section are severable, and the
invalidity of any provision of the section shall not affect other provisions of
the section which can be given effect without the invalid provision. (Ord.
1159, 10-8-2013; amd. Ord. 1237, 3-10-2020)
10-4-19: SOCIAL HOST/SOCIAL HOSTING:
   A.   Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following definitions
shall apply:
   ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE: Alcohol, spirits, liquor, wine, beer, and every liquid
or solid containing alcohol, spirits, wine, or beer, and which contains one-
half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume and which is fit for beverage
purposes either alone or when diluted, mixed, or combined with other
substances. This term includes intoxicating beverages and "low point beer" as
defined herein.
   GATHERING: A party, gathering, or event, where a group of three (3) or more
persons have assembled or are assembling for a social occasion or social
activity.
   IMMEDIATE FAMILY MEMBER: A parent, stepparent and/or legal guardian.
   INTOXICATING BEVERAGE: Any beverage containing more than three and two-
tenths percent (3.2%) alcohol by weight.
   LOW POINT BEER: Beverages containing more than one-half of one percent (1/
2 of 1%) alcohol by volume, and not more than three and two-tenths percent
(3.2%) alcohol by weight, including, but not limited to, beer or cereal malt
beverages obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion of barley or
other grain, malt or similar products.
   RESPONSIBLE PERSON AT A SOCIAL GATHERING: 1. Any person and/or persons who
have actual and/or apparent control of any unlicensed location, public or
private, and regardless of their age; or
      2.   Any person and/or persons at an unlicensed location who give or
otherwise provide any alcoholic and/or low point beer but do not accept
remuneration; provided, cover charges, admission fees, and/or nominal costs for
attending social gatherings at unlicensed locations shall not be considered
remuneration.
   UNLICENSED LOCATION: Any premises, grounds, buildings, rooms and/or other
property, regardless whether public or private, and regardless whether owned,
leased, rented or otherwise under the control of any person or persons
responsible for that property where there is a social gathering which is not
licensed by the city and/or state to sell alcoholic beverage or low point beer.
   B.   Prohibition For Allowing Persons Under Twenty One Years Of Age To
Consume Alcohol And/Or Low Point Beer At Unlicensed Locations:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any responsible person having real or
apparent control of any unlicensed location to knowingly host, permit, or allow
a gathering to take place at said location where even one person under twenty
one (21) years of age consumes an alcoholic beverage and/or low point beer,
whenever said responsible person either knows a person under twenty one (21)
years of age has consumed an alcoholic beverage and/or low point beer or
reasonably should have known that a person under twenty one (21) years of age
consumed an alcoholic beverage and/or low point beer and that responsible
person has not taken reasonable precautions to prevent the consumption of an
alcoholic beverage and/or low point beer by a person under twenty one (21)
years of age as set forth in subsection B2 of this section.
      2.   If persons under twenty one (21) years of age are present and
alcoholic beverage and/or low point beer are being consumed at that location,
the responsible person or persons shall take reasonable precautions to prevent
the consumption of alcoholic beverage and/or low point beer by any person under
twenty one (21) years of age at the gathering. Reasonable precautions include,
but are not limited to, controlling the quantity of such beverages, verifying
the age of persons attending, and supervising the activities of the persons
under twenty one (21) years of age present.
      3.   Any person at an unlicensed location who accepts remuneration for
any alcoholic beverage and/or low point beer that are being served or otherwise
provided shall be subject to all laws, licenses, rules and/or regulations as
those in the business of selling such beverages, as a licensed establishment;
provided, cover charges, admission fees, and/or nominal costs for attending
social gatherings at unlicensed locations shall not be considered remuneration.
      4.   This section shall not apply to:
         a.   Any use of alcoholic beverages and/or low point beer by a person
under twenty one (21) years of age that occurs within the confines of the
family home and under the direct supervision of an immediate family member; or
         b.   Any use of an alcoholic beverage by a person under twenty one
(21) years of age that occurs as part of any religious practice and/or
ceremony.
   C.   Exception: This section shall not apply where prohibited or preempted
by state or federal law. (Ord. 1167, 8-12-2014)
ARTICLE A. CURFEW FOR MINORS
SECTION:
10-4A-1: Short Title
10-4A-2: Definitions
10-4A-3: Curfew Hours
10-4A-4: Parental Responsibility
10-4A-5: Exceptions
10-4A-6: Special Functions
10-4A-7: Responsibility Of Owners Of Public Places
10-4A-8: Violations; Police Procedures
10-4A-9: Penalties
10-4A-1: SHORT TITLE:
   This article shall be known and may be cited as the ORDINANCE REGULATING THE
PRESENCE AND CONDUCT OF MINORS ON STREETS AND PUBLIC PLACES. (2000 Code § 10-
425)
10-4A-2: DEFINITIONS:
   For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in
the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number
include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely
directory.
   ADULT: A person who is age eighteen (18) years or older.
   CITY: The city of Seminole, Oklahoma.
   CUSTODIAN: Any person the age of eighteen (18) years or older, who is in
loco parentis to a juvenile.
   GUARDIAN: Any person other than a parent, who has legal guardianship of a
minor.
   MINOR: Any person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
   PARENT: The natural or adoptive parent of a minor.
   PUBLIC PLACE: Any street, alley, highway, sidewalk, park, playground or
place to which the general public has access and a right to resort for
business, entertainment, or other lawful purpose. A "public place" shall
include, but not be limited to, any store, shop, restaurant, tavern, bowling
alley, cafe, theater, drugstore, poolroom, shopping center, parking lot and any
place devoted to amusement or entertainment of the general public. It shall
also include the area immediately surrounding any of the above. (2000 Code §
10-425; amd. Ord. 1074, 3-11-2008, eff. 4-10-2008)
10-4A-3: CURFEW HOURS:
   It shall be unlawful for any minor to be present or remain in any public
place either on foot or in any vehicle, in, about or upon any place in the city
after eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Sunday through Thursday nights until six
o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the morning after; or between the hours of twelve
o'clock (12:00) midnight and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on Saturday and Sunday,
unless accompanied by a parent, guardian, custodian, or other adult person
having custody or control of such minor or unless the presence of such minor is
connected with or required by some legitimate employment, trade, profession, or
occupation. (2000 Code § 10-425)
10-4A-4: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
   It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having
custody or control of any minor under the age of eighteen (18) years to suffer
or permit, or by inefficient control to allow, such person to be on the streets
or sidewalks or on or in any public property or public place within the city
within the hours set forth in section 10-4A-3 of this article. However, the
provisions of this section do not apply to a minor accompanied by his parent,
guardian, custodian or other adult person having the care, custody or control
of the minor; or if the parent, guardian or other adult person herein has made
a missing person notification to the police department. (2000 Code § 10-425)
10-4A-5: EXCEPTIONS:
   The prohibitions in sections 10-4A-3 and 10-4A-4 of this article shall not
apply:
   A.   To a minor accompanied by the parent or guardian of such minor.
   B.   To a minor accompanied by an adult authorized by the parent or guardian
of such minor to take said parent's place in accompanying said minor for a
designated period of time and purpose within a specified area.
   C.   To a minor exercising first amendment rights protected by the United
States constitution, such as interstate travel, the free exercise of religion,
freedom of speech and the right of assembly. Such minor shall evidence the bona
fides of such exercise by possession of a written communication, signed by such
minor and countersigned by a parent of such minor, and with their home address
and telephone number, specifying when and where and in what manner said minor
will be on the streets at night (during hours when this article is otherwise
applicable to said minor) in the exercise of a first amendment right specified
in such communication.
   D.   In case of reasonable necessity, but only if the minor has in said
minor's possession a written communication signed by the minor, countersigned
by a parent of such minor evidencing their home address and telephone number,
and establishing such reasonable necessity relating to specified streets at a
designated time for a described purpose, including points of origin and
destination.
   E.   To a minor who is on the sidewalk of the place where such minor
resides, or on the sidewalk of either next door neighbor not communicating an
objection to the police officer.
   F.   To a minor returning home by a direct route from, and within thirty
(30) minutes of the termination of, a school activity, or an activity of a
religious or voluntary association, provided the minor has a written
communication in the minor's possession, countersigned by the parent indicating
the home address and telephone number, the purpose of the event, when, where
and in what manner said minor will be on the streets at night.
   G.   To a minor carrying a certified card of employment, briefly identifying
the minor, the addresses of his home and his place of employment and his hours
of employment, or carries a valid proof of employment which may include the
latest payroll receipt not over thirty (30) days old. (2000 Code § 10-425)
10-4A-6: SPECIAL FUNCTIONS:
   Any minor attending a special function or entertainment of any church,
school, club, or other organization that requires such minor to be out at a
later hour than that called for in section 10-4A-3 of this article shall be
exempt from the provisions of section 10-4A-4 of this article; provided the
church, school, club or other organization shall register in advance with the
chief of police or his designee, to have the minors stay out to this later
hour. The registrant shall state the time the function or entertainment shall
end, and the minors who attend the function shall be required to be in their
homes or usual places of abode within one-half (1/2) hour after the function is
ended. (2000 Code § 10-425)
 
10-4A-7: RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNERS OF PUBLIC PLACES:
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation operating or having
charge of any public place to knowingly permit or suffer the presence of minors
under the age of eighteen (18) years between the hours set forth in section 10-
4A-3 of this article. (2000 Code § 10-425)
10-4A-8: VIOLATIONS; POLICE PROCEDURES:
   A.   Detecting Minor In Violation; Notice To Parents: Any police officer,
upon finding a minor in violation of section 10-4A-3 of this article, shall
ascertain the name and address of such minor and warn the minor that he is in
violation of curfew and shall direct the minor to proceed at once to his or her
home or usual place of abode. The police officer shall notify the parents,
guardian, or person having custody and control of such minor.
   B.   Failure Of Juvenile To Follow Police Instructions: If such minor
refuses to heed such warning or direction by any police officer or refuses to
give such police officer his correct name and address, or if the minor has been
warned on a previous occasion that he or she is in violation of curfew, he or
she shall be taken to the police department and the parent, guardian or other
adult person having the care and custody of such minor shall be notified to
come and take charge of the minor. If the parent, guardian or other adult
person above cannot be located or fails to come and take charge of the minor,
the minor shall be released to the juvenile authorities.
   C.   Filing Report With Police Chief: In any event, such police officer
shall, within twenty four (24) hours, file a written report with the chief of
police, or shall participate to the extent of the information for which he is
responsible. Said report shall be treated, for purposes of juvenile records, in
accordance with the statutes of the state.
   D.   Release Of Minor To Parent Or Juvenile Authorities: When a parent,
immediately called, has come to take charge of the minor, and the appropriate
information has been recorded, the minor shall be released to the custody of
such parent. If the parent cannot be located, or fails to take charge of the
minor, then the minor shall be released to the juvenile authorities; except to
the extent that, in accordance with police regulations approved in advance by
juvenile authorities, the minor may temporarily be entrusted to a relative,
neighbor or other person who will, on behalf of the parent, assume the
responsibility of caring for the minor pending the availability or arrival of a
parent.
   E.   First Violation: In the case of a first violation by a minor, the chief
of police shall cause to be personally delivered, or by certified mail, send to
a parent, written notice of said violation with a warning that any subsequent
violation will result in full enforcement of this article, including
enforcement of parental responsibility and of applicable penalties. (2000 Code
§ 10-425)
10-4A-9: PENALTIES:
   Any minor violating the provisions of this article shall be dealt with in
accordance with the juvenile court law and procedure 1 . Any parent, guardian
or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor violating this
article shall, after having been previously notified under subsection 10-4A-8E
of this article, be fined pursuant to section 1-1-8 of this code for each
offense. (2000 Code § 10-425; amd. Ord. 1074, 3-11-2008, eff. 4-10-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. 10 OS § 7303-1.2 for Oklahoma juvenile code.
ARTICLE B. PREVENTION OF YOUTH ACCESS TO TOBACCO
SECTION:
10-4B-1: Findings And Intent
10-4B-2: Definitions
10-4B-3: Distribution And Sales To Minors Prohibited
10-4B-4: Receipt Of Tobacco Products By Minors
10-4B-5: Distribution Of Tobacco Product Samples
10-4B-6: Sale Of Tobacco Except In Original Sealed Packaging
10-4B-7: Public Access To Displayed Tobacco Products
10-4B-8: Report Of Violations And Compliance Checks
10-4B-9: Nonretaliation
10-4B-1: FINDINGS AND INTENT:
   The city council finds that youth addiction to tobacco products is a public
health problem with grave health consequences. In recognition that almost
ninety percent (90%) of all smokers begin smoking by the age of eighteen (18),
action is needed to curtail the easy access of minors to cigarettes and other
addictive tobacco products. Furthermore, the city council finds that the
Oklahoma state legislature has limited the powers granted to local governments
to address the problem of youth access to tobacco. Therefore, the intent of
this article is to: a) implement the strictest and most enforceable system
allowed under Oklahoma state law to prevent the illegal sale of cigarettes and
other tobacco products to minors; and b) periodically amend and update this
article as necessary to best utilize any applicable powers which may be
returned to Oklahoma municipalities in the future; and c) educate, encourage
and assist underage tobacco users in ceasing all use of addictive tobacco
products, preferably before daily use of such products is initiated. (Ord.
1150, 6-12-2012)
10-4B-2: DEFINITIONS:
   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall
have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning:
   CIGARETTE: Any product that contains nicotine, is intended to be burned or
heated under ordinary conditions of use and consists of or contains:
   A.   Any roll of tobacco wrapped in paper or in any substance not containing
tobacco;
   B.   Tobacco, in any form, that is functional in the product, which, because
of its appearance, the type of tobacco used in the filter, or its packaging and
labeling, is likely to be offered to, or purchased by, consumers as a cigarette
described in subsection A of this definition.
   The term "cigarette" includes "roll your own" (i.e., any tobacco which,
because of its appearance, type, packaging, or labeling is suitable for use and
likely to be offered to, or purchased by, consumers as tobacco for making
cigarettes). For purposes of this definition of cigarette, nine one-hundredths
(0.09) of an ounce of "roll your own" tobacco shall constitute one individual
"cigarette".
   PROOF OF AGE: A driver's license, license for identification only, or other
generally accepted means of identification that describes the individual as
eighteen (18) years of age or older and contains a photograph or other likeness
of the individual and appears on its face to be valid.
   SAMPLE: A tobacco product distributed to members of the public at no cost
for the purpose of promoting the product.
   SAMPLING: The distribution of samples to members of the public in a public
place.
   TOBACCO PRODUCT: Any product that contains tobacco and is intended for human
consumption.
   TRANSACTION SCAN: The process by which a seller checks, by means of a
transaction scan device, the validity of a driver's license or other government
issued photo identification.
   TRANSACTION SCAN DEVICE: Any commercial device or combination of devices
used at a point of sale or entry that is capable of deciphering in an
electronically readable format the information encoded on the magnetic strip or
bar code of a driver's license or other government issued photo identification.
(Ord. 1150, 6-12-2012)
10-4B-3: DISTRIBUTION AND SALES TO MINORS PROHIBITED:
   A.   Unlawful To Sell, Give Or Furnish Tobacco To Minors: It is unlawful for
any person to sell, give or furnish in any manner any tobacco product to
another person who is under eighteen (18) years of age, or to purchase in any
manner a tobacco product on behalf of any such person. It shall not be unlawful
for an employee under eighteen (18) years of age to handle tobacco products
when required in the performance of the employee's duties.
   B.   Demand For Proof Of Age: Any person engaged in the sale or distribution
of tobacco products shall demand proof of age from a prospective purchaser or
recipient if an ordinary person would conclude on the basis of appearance that
the prospective purchaser may be under eighteen (18) years of age. If an
individual engaged in the sale or distribution of tobacco products has demanded
and was shown proof of age from a prospective purchaser or recipient who is not
under eighteen (18) years of age, the failure to subsequently require proof of
age shall not constitute a violation of this section.
   C.   Defenses: Proof that the defendant demanded, was shown, and reasonably
relied upon proof of age shall be a defense to prosecution under subsection A
or B of this section. A person cited for violation of this section shall be
deemed to have reasonably relied upon proof of age, and such person shall not
be found guilty of such violation, if such person proves that:
      1.   The individual who purchased or received the tobacco product
presented a driver's license or other government issued photo identification
purporting to establish that such individual was eighteen (18) years of age or
older; and
      2.   The person cited for the violation confirmed the validity of the
driver's license or other government issued photo identification presented by
such individual by performing a transaction scan by means of a transaction scan
device.
      3.   Provided that this defense shall not relieve from liability any
person cited for a violation of this section if such person failed to exercise
reasonable diligence to determine whether the physical description and picture
appearing on the driver's license or other government issued photo
identification was that of the individual who presented it. The availability of
the defense described in this subsection does not affect the availability of
any other defense under any other provision of law.
   D.   Each Business Location A Separate Entity: For purposes of determining
the liability of a person controlling franchises or business operations in
multi-locations for any violation of subsection A or B of this section, each
individual franchise or business location shall be deemed a separate entity.
   E.   Fines, Fees Or Costs: When a person is convicted or enters a plea and
receives a continued sentence for a violation of subsection A or B of this
section, the total of any fines, fees or costs shall not exceed the following:
      1.   One hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense;
      2.   Two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense within a two
(2) year period following the first offense; and
      3.   Three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the third or subsequent offense
within a two (2) year period following the first offense. (Ord. 1150, 6-12-
2012)
10-4B-4: RECEIPT OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS BY MINORS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person who is under eighteen (18) years of age
to purchase, receive, or have in his possession a tobacco product, or to
present or offer to any person any purported proof of age which is false or
fraudulent for the purpose of purchasing or receiving any tobacco product. It
shall not be unlawful for an employee under age eighteen (18) years of age to
handle tobacco products when required in the performance of the employee's
duties.
   B.   When a person is convicted or enters a plea and receives a continued
sentence for a violation of subsection A of this section, the total of any
fines, fees, or costs shall not exceed the following:
      1.   One hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first offense; and
      2.   Two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a second or subsequent offense
within a one year period following the first offense. (Ord. 1150, 6-12-2012)
10-4B-5: DISTRIBUTION OF TOBACCO PRODUCT SAMPLES:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to distribute tobacco products or product
samples to any person under eighteen (18) years of age.
   B.   No person shall distribute tobacco product samples in or on any public
street, sidewalk, or park that is within three hundred feet (300') of any
playground, school or other facility when the facility is being used primarily
by persons under eighteen (18) years of age.
   C.   When a person is convicted or enters a plea and receives a continued
sentence for a violation of subsection A or B of this section, the total of any
fines, fees, or costs shall not exceed the following:
      1.   One hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense;
      2.   Two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense; and
      3.   Three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the third or subsequent offense.
(Ord. 1150, 6-12-2012)
10-4B-6: SALE OF TOBACCO EXCEPT IN ORIGINAL SEALED PACKAGING:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to sell cigarettes except in the
original, sealed package in which they were placed by the manufacturer.
   B.   When a person is convicted or enters a plea and receives a continued
sentence for a violation of this section, the total of any fines, fees, or
costs shall not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. (Ord.
1150, 6-12-2012)
10-4B-7: PUBLIC ACCESS TO DISPLAYED TOBACCO PRODUCTS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person or retail store to display or offer for
sale tobacco products in any manner that allows public access to the tobacco
product without assistance from the person displaying the tobacco product or an
employee or the owner of the store. The provisions of this subsection shall not
apply to retail stores which do not admit into the store persons under eighteen
(18) years of age.
   B.   When a person is convicted or enters a plea and receives a continued
sentence for a violation of this section, the total of any fines, fees, or
costs shall not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. (Ord.
1150, 6-12-2012)
10-4B-8: REPORT OF VIOLATIONS AND COMPLIANCE CHECKS:
   A.   Any conviction for a violation of this article and any compliance
checks conducted by the police department pursuant to subsection B of this
section shall be reported in writing to the alcoholic beverage laws enforcement
(ABLE) commission within thirty (30) days of the conviction or compliance
check. Such reports shall be compiled in the manner prescribed by the ABLE
commission. Convictions shall be reported by the court clerk or his designee
and compliance checks shall be reported by the chief of police or his designee.
   B.   Persons under eighteen (18) years of age may be enlisted by the police
department to assist in enforcement of this article pursuant to the rules of
the ABLE commission. (Ord. 1150, 6-12-2012)
10-4B-9: NONRETALIATION:
   No person shall discharge, refuse to hire or in any manner retaliate against
any employee, applicant for employment or customer because such employee,
applicant, or customer reported violations of any provisions of this article.
(Ord. 1150, 6-12-2012)
ARTICLE C. SPRAY PAINT SALES TO MINORS
SECTION:
10-4C-1: Short Title
10-4C-2: Definitions
10-4C-3: Prohibited Conduct
10-4C-4: Posting Signs Prohibiting Sales To Minors
10-4C-5: Providing Spray Paint To Minors
10-4C-6: Penalty
10-4C-1: SHORT TITLE:
   This article shall be known and may be cited as the SPRAY PAINT ORDINANCE.
(2000 Code § 10-427)
10-4C-2: DEFINITIONS:
   For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in
the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number
the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely
directory.
   ADULT: A person who is age eighteen (18) years or older.
   CITY: The city of Seminole, Oklahoma.
   CUSTODIAN: Any person the age of eighteen (18) years or older, who is in
loco parentis to a juvenile.
   GUARDIAN: Any person other than a parent, who has legal guardianship of a
minor.
   MINOR: Any person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
   PARENT: The natural or adoptive parent of a minor.
   PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, partnership or corporation
selling or offering for sale any item prohibited by this article. (2000 Code §
10-427; amd. Ord. 1074, 3-11-2008, eff. 4-10-2008)
10-4C-3: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
   A.   Sales To Minors Restricted: No person shall sell to any minor any
aerosol container of paint (spray paint) capable of defacing property unless
such minor is accompanied by parent or guardian.
   B.   Proof Of Age And Identity Required: Any person selling or offering for
sale any aerosol container of paint shall require bona fide evidence of
majority and identity. Bona fide evidence of majority and identity shall be
established only by a document issued by a federal, state, county or municipal
government, including, but not limited to, a motor vehicle operator's license,
a registration certificate issued under the federal selective service act or an
identification card issued to a member of the armed forces.
   C.   Defense To Criminal Prosecution: Proof that the defendant, or his
employee or agent, demanded, was shown and acted in reliance upon such bona
fide evidence in any sale transaction forbidden hereby shall be a defense to
any criminal prosecution thereof. (2000 Code § 10-427)
10-4C-4: POSTING SIGNS PROHIBITING SALES TO MINORS:
   Any person who owns, manages or operates a place of business wherein aerosol
containers of paint capable of defacing property are sold shall conspicuously
post at the place of display of said containers for sale and at the place of
sale (cash register) a sign in letters at least one-half inch (1/2") in height,
"Spray Paint Shall Not Be Sold To Minors". (2000 Code § 10-427)
 
10-4C-5: PROVIDING SPRAY PAINT TO MINORS:
   Any person who has reached the age of majority who shall give, trade or
otherwise provide to any minor any aerosol container of paint used in the
actual application of graffiti or defacement of property or used as an
intoxicant by such minor shall be guilty of an offense and shall, upon
conviction thereof, be punished as prescribed in section 10-4C-6 of this
article. (2000 Code § 10-427)
10-4C-6: PENALTY:
   The penalty for violation of this article shall be incarceration for a
period not exceeding thirty (30) days in jail and/or a fine pursuant to section
1-1-8 of this code for each offense. (2000 Code § 10-427; amd. Ord. 1074, 3-11-
2008, eff. 4-10-2008)
CHAPTER 5
OFFENSES AGAINST PERSONS
SECTION:
10-5-1: Assault And Battery Prohibited
10-5-1: ASSAULT AND BATTERY PROHIBITED:
   A.   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following definitions
shall apply:
   ASSAULT: Any wilful and unlawful attempt or offer with force or violence to
do a corporal hurt to another.
   BATTERY: A wilful and unlawful use of force or violence upon the person of
another.
   B.   Prohibited Act: It is unlawful to commit an assault or an assault and
battery within the city. (Ord. 935, 12-14-2000)
   C.   Penalty: Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of an
offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to penalty as provided
in section 1-1-8 of this code. (Ord. 935, 12-14-2000; amd. Ord. 1074, 3-11-
2008, eff. 4-10-2008)
CHAPTER 6
OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC AUTHORITY
SECTION:
10-6-1: Resisting An Officer
10-6-2: Refusing Or Failing To Assist An Officer
10-6-3: Assault Or Battery Upon Police Or Other Law Officer
10-6-4: Offenses Relating To Prisoners
10-6-5: Impersonating An Officer Or Employee
10-6-6: False Alarms
10-6-7: False Representation To An Officer
10-6-8: Removal Of Barricades
10-6-9: Resisting Public Officials
10-6-1: RESISTING AN OFFICER:
   A.   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall
have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
   OBSTRUCTION OF: The words "obstruction of" shall, in addition to their
common meaning, include:
      1.   Flight by one sought to be arrested before the arresting officer can
restrain him and after notice is given that he is under arrest;
      2.   Any violence toward or any resistance or opposition to the arresting
officer after the arrested party is actually placed under arrest and before he
is under arrest; or
      3.   Refusal by the arrested party to give his name and make his identity
known to the arresting officer.
   RESISTING AN OFFICER: The intentional opposition or resistance to, or
obstruction of, an individual acting in his official capacity, and authorized
by law to make a lawful arrest or seizure of property, or to serve any lawful
process or court order, when the offender knows or has reason to know that the
person arresting, seizing property, or serving process is acting in his
official capacity.
   B.   Resisting An Officer: It is unlawful to resist, oppose or assault, or
in any way interfere with the police chief or any person duly authorized to act
as such, while the officer or person is discharging or attempting to discharge
his official duties within the limits of the city.
   C.   Assisting Escape: It is unlawful for any person to warn or signal
another so as to assist such other person to flee, escape or evade an officer
seeking to make an arrest, or for any person to bar or lock any door or barrier
in the face of or in front of an approaching officer. (2000 Code § 10-601)
10-6-2: REFUSING OR FAILING TO ASSIST AN OFFICER:
   A.   An officer of the city making or about to make an arrest, or executing
or about to execute a warrant or other process, in accordance with the
ordinances of the city or with state or federal law, or suppressing or about to
suppress a riot, affray or unlawful assembly, may call upon persons to assist
him in making such arrest, executing such process or suppressing such riot,
affray or unlawful assembly.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person lawfully called upon thus to assist an
officer of the city to refuse or fail to do so. (2000 Code § 10-602)
10-6-3: ASSAULT OR BATTERY UPON POLICE OR OTHER LAW OFFICER:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person, without justifiable or excusable cause,
to knowingly commit any assault, battery or assault and battery upon the person
of a police officer or other officer of the law while in the performance of his
duties.
   B.   Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of an offense and,
upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 of this
code. (2000 Code § 10-603)
10-6-4: OFFENSES RELATING TO PRISONERS:
   A.   Rescuing Prisoners: It is unlawful for any person, in any illegal
manner, to set at liberty, rescue or attempt to set at liberty, any prisoner
from any officer or employee of the city having legal custody of the same or
from jail or other place of confinement by the city, or to assist such prisoner
in any manner to escape from such prison or custody either before or after
conviction, including escape from a vehicle of confinement. (2000 Code § 10-
604; amd. Ord. 1074, 3-11-2008, eff. 4-10-2008)
   B.   Escape Of Prisoners: It is unlawful for any person confined in jail or
other place of confinement by the city, or working upon the streets or other
public places of the city in pursuance of any judgment, or otherwise held in
legal custody by authority of the city, to escape or attempt to escape from any
jail, prison or custody. (2000 Code § 10-605; amd. Ord. 1074, 3-11-2008, eff.
4-10-2008)
   C.   Furnishing Weapons To Prisoners: It is unlawful for any person to
furnish or attempt to furnish or take into jail or to deliver or attempt to
deliver to any prisoner therein confined, or in the custody of any officer, any
weapon, tool, intoxicating liquors, drug or other article without the consent
of the officer in charge. (2000 Code § 10-606)
10-6-5: IMPERSONATING AN OFFICER OR EMPLOYEE:
   It is unlawful for any person to impersonate any officer or employee of the
city, falsely represent himself to be an officer or employee of the city, or
exercise or attempt to exercise any of the duties, functions or powers of an
officer or employee of the city without being duly authorized to do so. (2000
Code § 10-607)
10-6-6: FALSE ALARMS:
   It is unlawful for any person to turn in a false alarm of any nature or in
any manner to deceive or attempt to deceive the fire department or police
department or any officer or employee thereof with reference to any fire alarm
or reported fire, accident or other emergency or knowingly to cause the fire
department or police department or its officers or employees to make a useless
run. (2000 Code § 10-608)
10-6-7: FALSE REPRESENTATION TO AN OFFICER:
   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, or any agent or employee
thereof, knowingly to make any material misrepresentation to any officer,
employee or agency of the city government in any official application to, or
official dealing or negotiation with, such officer or agency; or to commit
perjury before any tribunal or officer of the city. (2000 Code § 10-609)
10-6-8: REMOVAL OF BARRICADES:
   It is unlawful for any person, except by proper authority, to remove any
barricade or obstruction placed by authority of the city to keep traffic off
any pavement, street, curb, sidewalk or other area. (2000 Code § 10-610)
10-6-9: RESISTING PUBLIC OFFICIALS:
   It is unlawful for any person knowingly or wilfully to:
   A.   Resist, oppose or obstruct the chief of police, any other police
officer, the municipal judge, or any other officer or employee of the city in
the discharge of his official duties;
   B.   Threaten or otherwise intimidate or attempt to intimidate any such
officer or employee from the discharge of his official duties; or
   C.   Assault or beat, or revile, abuse, be disrespectful to, use abusive or
indecent language toward or about, any such officer or employee while such
officer or employee is in the discharge of his official duties. (2000 Code §
10-611)
TITLE 11
PARKS, RECREATION AND CEMETERY
CHAPTER 1
LIBRARY BOARD
SECTION:
11-1-1: Board Created
11-1-2: Members; Terms
11-1-3: Filling Vacancies
11-1-4: Organization; Powers
11-1-5: Rules And Regulations
11-1-6: Annual Report Required
11-1-7: Donations
11-1-8: Council Power
11-1-9: Violation; Penalty
11-1-1: BOARD CREATED:
   There is created a library board to consist of six (6) members who shall be
citizens of the city appointed with reference to their fitness by the mayor
with the consent of the council. Members shall serve without compensation.
(2000 Code § 11-101; amd. Ord. 1068, 1-8-2008, eff. 2-7-2008)
11-1-2: MEMBERS; TERMS:
   Members of the library board shall be appointed for a term of three (3)
years, and the term of only two (2) members shall regularly expire each year.
Appointments shall be made before May 1 of each year. Any member may be removed
for cause by the mayor with the consent of the council. (2000 Code § 11-102)
11-1-3: FILLING VACANCIES:
   Vacancies on the board occasioned by removals, resignations or otherwise
shall be reported to the council, and shall be filled in the same manner as
original appointments are made. (2000 Code § 11-103)
11-1-4: ORGANIZATION; POWERS:
   A.   Officers; Bylaws: The board shall, immediately after appointment, meet
and organize by the election of one of their number as president and such other
officers as they may deem necessary. They shall make and adopt bylaws, rules
and regulations for their own guidance and for the government of the library
and reading rooms as may be expedient, not inconsistent with this chapter.
   B.   Control Of Expenditures: They shall have the exclusive control of the
expenditures of all monies collected and placed to the credit of the library
fund and of the supervision, care and custody of the grounds, rooms or
buildings constructed, leased or set apart for that purpose. All monies
received for the library shall be deposited in the treasury of the city to the
credit of the library fund, and shall be kept separate and apart from other
money of the city, and shall be paid out only upon properly authenticated
vouchers of the library board, approved by the mayor and council.
   C.   Powers:
      1.   Librarian And Assistants, Appointment: The board shall have the
power to appoint a suitable librarian and necessary assistants, fix their
compensation, and remove such appointees for cause, and shall, in general,
carry out the spirit and intent of this chapter.
      2.   Accept Donations: The board shall have the power to accept, or in
its discretion to decline, donations tendered as provided in this chapter for
the purpose of maintaining and augmenting collections other than of printed
books and periodicals.
      3.   Powers Subject To City Approval: All powers delegated to the board
shall be exercised subject to the approval of the mayor and council. (2000 Code
§ 11-104)
11-1-5: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   The library or reading room shall be subject to such reasonable rules and
regulations as the board may adopt in order to render the use of the library
and reading room to the greatest number. The board may exclude from the use of
the library and reading room any and all persons who wilfully violate such
rules. (2000 Code § 11-105)
11-1-6: ANNUAL REPORT REQUIRED:
   The board shall make, on or before April 1 in each year, an annual report to
the council stating:
   A.   The condition of their trust on March 1 of the year;
   B.   The various sums of money received from the library fund and other
sources;
   C.   How much money has been expended and for what purposes;
   D.   The number of books and periodicals on hand;
   E.   The number of books added by purchase, gift or otherwise during the
year;
   F.   The number of books lost or missing; (2000 Code § 11-106; amd. Ord.
1068, 1-8-2008, eff. 2-7-2008)
   G.   The number of persons attending;
   H.   The amount of books loaned out;
   I.   The general character and kind of such books; and
   J.   Such other statistics, information and suggestions as they may deem of
general interest. (2000 Code § 11-106)
11-1-7: DONATIONS:
   Any person desiring to make donations of money, personal property or real
estate, for the benefit of the library or for the establishment, maintenance or
endowment of public lectures in connection with the library upon any subject
designated by the donor in the field of literature, science and the arts shall
have the right to vest the title to the money and personal property or real
estate so donated in the board, to be held and controlled by the board when
accepted according to the terms of the deed, gift, devise or bequest of such
property. However, the establishment, maintenance or public lectures in the
interest of any political party, politics or sectarian religion are expressly
prohibited. The board shall be held and considered to be special trustee of any
donations and endowments as provided in this section. (2000 Code § 11-107)
11-1-8: COUNCIL POWER:
   The library and reading room may be used for such other public purposes as
the council may deem proper and shall always be subject to such reasonable
rules and regulations as the council may adopt, in order to render the use of
the library and reading room of the greatest benefit to the greatest number.
(2000 Code § 11-108)
11-1-9: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Any person who wilfully violates any rules and regulations regularly
adopted by the board for the government, care and use of the library and
reading room is guilty of an offense and punished accordingly.
   B.   Any person who destroys or defaces any book, periodical or other
property of the library, or who fails to return any such property at such time
as the same should have been returned, and fails to comply with the regulations
of the board thereto, is guilty of an offense and punished accordingly. (2000
Code § 11-109)
CHAPTER 2
PARK BOARD
SECTION:
11-2-1: Board Created
11-2-2: Members; Terms
11-2-3: Vacancies; Removal Of Members
11-2-4: Quorum; Meetings
11-2-5: Officers
11-2-6: Duties
11-2-7: Rules And Regulations !2R!
11-2-1: BOARD CREATED:
There is created a park board which shall consist of five (5) citizens, who
shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. (Ord.
984, 1-11-2005)
11-2-2: MEMBERS; TERMS:
Two (2) of the five (5) members of the park board shall be appointed for three
(3) year terms while two (2) members shall be appointed for two (2) year terms
and one member shall be appointed for a one year term. After the initial
appointments, all subsequent appointments shall be for a term of three (3)
years. The mayor, city manager and director of public works shall be ex officio
members of the board. (2000 Code §11-202; amd. Ord. 1068, 1-8-2008, eff. 2-7-
2008)
11-2-3: VACANCIES; REMOVAL OF MEMBERS:
In the event of the death, resignation or removal of any member of the park
board, the mayor, with the consent of the city council, shall appoint a new
member to serve for the unexpired portion of the term vacated. If any regular
member shall be absent for four (4) consecutive meetings, his office shall
automatically be vacated and a new member shall be appointed by the mayor with
the consent of the city council. The mayor, with the consent of the city
council, may for good cause shown remove any member of the park board. (2000
Code §11-203)
11-2-4: QUORUM; MEETINGS:
   A.   Quorum: Three (3) voting members of the park board shall constitute a
quorum for the transaction of business. (2000 Code §11-204)
   B.   Meetings: Regular meetings of the park board shall be on a quarterly
basis at times and places to be determined by the board. Special meetings may
be called as deemed necessary for the transaction of business. (Ord. 1068, 1-8-
2008, eff. 2-7-2008)
11-2-5: OFFICERS:
The park board shall select one member to serve as chairman, one member to
serve as vice chairman and one member to serve as secretary. (2000 Code §11-
205)
11-2-6: DUTIES:
The duties of the park board shall be to coordinate and to recommend to the
city manager, mayor and city council various programs, objectives, plans and
courses of action with respect to the parks, recreational and sports
activities, and cemetery activities in the city. (Ord. 984, 1-11-2005)
11-2-7: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The park board shall have the authority to promulgate rules and regulations for
the operation of parks, recreational and sports activities, and cemetery
activities in the city. Anyone violating the published rules and regulations of
the park board shall be guilty of a misdemeanor for which the maximum penalty
shall be a fine and punishment as provided in section 1-1-8 of this code. The
rules and regulations shall be subject to review and approval of the city
council. (Ord. 1068, 1-8-2008, eff. 2-7-2008)
CHAPTER 3
LAKE DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
SECTION:
11-3-1: Commission Created
11-3-2: Terms
11-3-3: Ex Officio Members
11-3-4: Quorum
11-3-5: Member Appointments
11-3-6: Organization; Meetings
11-3-7: Personnel; Compensation
11-3-8: Duties
11-3-9: Rules And Regulations
11-3-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
   There is hereby created within and for the city a lake development
commission, which commission shall consist of five (5) citizens, as hereinafter
provided. The members of the commission shall be nominated by the mayor and
confirmed by the city council. The appointments shall be solely with reference
to their fitness and without reference to party affiliations, and the members
shall serve without compensation, except as may be hereinafter provided. (Ord.
986, 1-11-2005)
11-3-2: TERMS:
   Members of the lake development commission shall hold office for terms of
three (3) years, with exception that in the first instance, one shall be
appointed to serve for a term of one year, two (2) for a term of two (2) years
and two (2) for a term of three (3) years. When a vacancy occurs, then the
appointment shall be made to fill the unexpired term. The terms as set out
herein shall be from July 1 to June 30. (Ord. 978, 10-12-2004)
11-3-3: EX OFFICIO MEMBERS:
   The mayor shall be an ex officio member of the lake development commission
as herein created and the mayor may designate any other member or official of
the city as an additional ex officio member of the commission to serve as
members thereof and receive no compensation, other than any affixed salary as
set by the mayor and city council or by ordinance creating same. (2000 Code §
11-403)
11-3-4: QUORUM:
   At least three (3) members of the lake development commission shall
constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. However, no action shall
be taken and be binding upon the commission unless concurred in by not less
than a majority of all members comprising the lake development commission.
(Ord. 978, 10-12-2004)
11-3-5: MEMBER APPOINTMENTS:
   The mayor shall appoint the members of the lake development commission
subject to approval and confirmation of the city council as provided in this
chapter. (2000 Code § 11-405)
11-3-6: ORGANIZATION; MEETINGS:
   A.   Commission Officers: The members of the lake development commission as
hereby created shall meet within ten (10) days after their appointment and
confirmation and organize by electing from their members a chairman, vice
chairman and secretary, except that the mayor shall, at his option, upon
appointment of the members of the commission in the first instance, have power
to name one of the members of the commission as chairman thereof; the member so
named as chairman by the mayor shall serve and act as such chairman of the
commission during the term of his office. Thereafter, the chairman of the
commission shall be elected by the commission.
   B.   Bylaws: The commission shall adopt from time to time such bylaws,
regulations and amendments thereto as may be necessary to effectuate the
purpose of this chapter.
   C.   Meetings: The regular meeting of the lake development commission after
the organizational meeting as set forth herein shall be the last week of July
of each year. However, a chairman of the commission, or mayor as ex officio
member thereof, may call a special meeting of such commission at any time as
may be deemed necessary for the transaction of any business of and by and
through the commission. At the regular meeting in the last week of July of each
year as provided herein, the commission shall elect such officers that may be
necessary for the ensuing year. (2000 Code § 11-406)
11-3-7: PERSONNEL; COMPENSATION:
   The members of the lake development commission as hereby created shall serve
without pay. The commission shall have power and authority to employ engineers,
attorneys, clerks, a manager or any other help deemed necessary, subject,
however, to the approval of the mayor and city council. The salary and
compensation of such employees, as the case may be, shall be fixed by the city
council and shall be paid out of the city treasury, and other officers and
employees and any other expenses incurred by the commission shall be paid out
of the city treasury as other legal expenses of the city government. (2000 Code
§ 11-407)
11-3-8: DUTIES:
   The lake development commission as hereby created shall have the
supervision, control, maintenance and operation and authority over and have
complete development and protection of the water system within the Seminole
Sportsman Lake area and may investigate such matters pertaining thereto for the
betterment of the Seminole Sportsman Lake for and on behalf of the city. The
commission may make recommendations as it may deem advisable providing for the
operation, development and maintenance of the lake area; and cause any surveys,
maps or plans in connection therewith as they may deem advisable and necessary
in their best judgment. All plans, plats or replats, surveys and
recommendations by the commission shall be submitted to the city council for
final approval or rejection. (2000 Code § 11-408; amd. Ord. 1068, 1-8-2008,
eff. 2-7-2008)
11-3-9: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   The lake development commission shall have the authority to promulgate rules
and regulations for the operation of Seminole Sportsman Lake and the
surrounding area. Anyone violating the published rules and regulations of the
lake development commission shall be guilty of a misdemeanor for which the
maximum penalty shall be a fine and punishment as provided in section 1-1-8 of
this code. The rules and regulations shall be subject to the review and
approval of the city council. (2000 Code § 11-409)
CHAPTER 4
PUBLIC PARKS
ARTICLE A. REGULATIONS
SECTION:
11-4A-1: Designated Parks
11-4A-2: Defacing Property
11-4A-3: Injuring Plant Life
11-4A-4: Littering
11-4A-5: Vendor Or Merchant License Required
11-4A-6: Motorized Vehicles Prohibited
11-4A-7: Camping Restricted
11-4A-8: Advertising Prohibited In Parks
11-4A-9: Use Of Parks For Picnics
11-4A-10: Trespassing On Reserved Areas
11-4A-11: Attaching Of Wires To Trees And Structures
11-4A-12: Climbing Of Trees
11-4A-13: Animals And Fowl
11-4A-14: Discharge Of Firearms
11-4A-15: Disorderly Conduct
11-4A-16: Begging, Solicitations
11-4A-17: Violation; Penalty
11-4A-1: DESIGNATED PARKS:
   All places owned by the city and used as parks are declared to be public
parks within the meaning of this chapter and are subject to all rules and
regulations set out in this article. (2000 Code § 11-601)
11-4A-2: DEFACING PROPERTY:
   No person shall write upon or mark or deface in any manner or use in any
improper way any water closet, park seat, any building, fence or other property
in any park. (2000 Code § 11-602)
11-4A-3: INJURING PLANT LIFE:
   No person shall break, cut, mutilate or injure, remove or carry away any
trees, shrubs, plants, flowers, stone or stone walk, bench, stand, structure,
fence or anything whatsoever in or upon any park. (2000 Code § 11-603)
11-4A-4: LITTERING:
   No person shall throw stones or rubbish of any kind into any lake, pond or
stream or other place in the parks, except into receptacles designated for that
purpose. No person shall foul in any manner any pool, spring or drinking
fountain in any park. (2000 Code § 11-605)
11-4A-5: VENDOR OR MERCHANT LICENSE REQUIRED:
   No person shall set up any booth, table, stand or device for vending or
retailing any candies, ice cream or other articles whatsoever, without first
obtaining a license therefor from the city and complying with all applicable
ordinances governing itinerant vendors and merchants. (2000 Code § 11-606)
11-4A-6: MOTORIZED VEHICLES PROHIBITED:
   Motorized vehicles, including any "motor vehicle" or "motorcycle" as defined
in section 15-1-4 of this code, shall not be permitted in a public park except
on the roadway and surface of the dedicated public streets or roads in the
park. (2000 Code § 11-607)
11-4A-7: CAMPING RESTRICTED:
   A.   Prohibited Act: It is unlawful for any person to camp overnight in any
place owned by the city and used as a municipal park. This section shall not
apply to self-contained motor homes on designated, paved parking lots adjacent
to the parks.
   B.   Exception, Council Approval: Any deviation from subsection A of this
section shall require the approval of the city council. (2000 Code § 11-608)
11-4A-8: ADVERTISING PROHIBITED IN PARKS:
   A.   Advertising Or Distributing Circulars: No person shall advertise in any
manner or distribute or hand out any circulars, handbills or posters of any
kind or of any commodity or other thing in any public park.
   B.   Affixing Handbills To Trees, Buildings: No person shall affix any
circulars, handbills or posters of any kind on any tree, lamppost, hydrant,
curbstone, sidewalk, coping, flagpole, fence, wall, building or other place in
any public park or on any street, avenue, alley or other public grounds under
the supervision of the city.
   C.   Driving Animal Or Vehicle Displaying Advertising: No person shall drive
any animal or vehicle displaying any advertising of any kind in or through any
public park in the city or under its supervision without prior approval of city
council. (2000 Code § 11-609)
11-4A-9: USE OF PARKS FOR PICNICS:
   A.   Hours: Unless otherwise posted, no person shall use the parks of the
city from dusk to dawn, with the exception of organized groups approved by the
director of public works. (2000 Code § 11-610; amd. Ord. 1068, 1-8-2008, eff.
2-7-2008)
   B.   Garbage Cleanup: It shall be the duty of any person using the parks of
the city for the purpose of luncheons, picnics or meals of any kind to collect
all waste, rubbish and garbage and to place the same in receptacles provided
for that purpose. (2000 Code § 11-610)
11-4A-10: TRESPASSING ON RESERVED AREAS:
   No person shall go or walk upon any space in any public park reserved for
flowers or other plants, or appropriated to any special use, or invade any plot
reserved by the city for shrubbery, grass or flowers, or for other special
purposes. (2000 Code § 11-611)
11-4A-11: ATTACHING OF WIRES TO TREES AND STRUCTURES:
   A.   No person, without a written permit from the director of public works,
shall attach any electric wires, insulator or other device of any character to
any tree, plant or structure in any park.
   B.   No person shall establish, erect or maintain any telegraph wires,
telephone wires or electric light and power wires, or construction for the
support of the same, in, through, or across any public park, except with the
written permission of the director of public works. (2000 Code § 11-612; amd.
Ord. 1068, 1-8-2008, eff. 2-7-2008)
11-4A-12: CLIMBING OF TREES:
   No person shall climb any trees within any public park of the city. (2000
Code § 11-613)
11-4A-13: ANIMALS AND FOWL:
   A.   Running At Large:
      1.   No person shall permit any horse, cow or other domestic animal to go
in or run at large in the public parks of the city, and all such animals shall
be taken up and impounded and disposed of as provided by this code.
      2.   No person shall permit any domestic fowl which belong to him or are
in his possession to escape into or run in any public park. (2000 Code § 11-
614)
   B.   Chasing, Killing Or Trapping: No person shall chase, kill, set snares
for, pet or tease any rabbit, squirrel, bird, fish or any other animal or thing
belonging to the city in any parks, or kept therein, except as permitted by the
park board. (2000 Code § 11-614; amd. Ord. 1068, 1-8-2008, eff. 2-7-2008)
11-4A-14: DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS:
   No person shall discharge any firearms in any public park. (2000 Code § 11-
615)
11-4A-15: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
   No person shall be guilty of disorderly, unchaste, or lewd conduct, or of
habitual loafing or sleeping on the ground or benches, or make, aid or assist
in making any disorderly noise, riot or breach of the peace within the limits
of any public park belonging to the city. (2000 Code § 11-616)
11-4A-16: BEGGING, SOLICITATIONS:
   No person shall solicit, beg or accept any alms or gifts for charitable or
other purposes in any public park within the city or belonging to the city.
(2000 Code § 11-617)
11-4A-17: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   Any person who shall violate any provision of this article, either by doing
anything which is prohibited or by failing or refusing to do that which is
commanded, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-
1-8 of this code; each day of such violation shall be a separate and distinct
offense, and violators shall be held liable for restitution of any damages
caused by their actions. (2000 Code § 11-618)
ARTICLE B. PARK USE FEES
SECTION:
11-4B-1: Fees For Park Uses
11-4B-2: Responsibility For Collection Of Fees
11-4B-3: Review Of Rates
11-4B-4: Park User Fee Fund
11-4B-5: Penalty
11-4B-1: FEES FOR PARK USES:
   A.   Fees Enumerated: The city parks department is hereby authorized and
directed to collect the following fees for use of park facilities:
1. Seminole High School               $1,000.00 annual
2. Seminole state college             1,000.00 annual lease
3. Seminole baseball association:     25.00/team
League play                           5.00/team
Tournament play
4. Seminole soccer association:       25.00/team
League play                           5.00/team
Tournament play
5. Men's softball association:        25.00/team
League play                           5.00/team
Tournament play
6. Seminole tiny chiefs               25.00/team
7. Seminole tennis association        1.00/match
 
   B.   Per Season Fees: Unless specified herein, the above charges represent
fee per season. (2000 Code § 11-621; amd. Ord. 1068, 1-8-2008, eff. 2-7-2008)
11-4B-2: RESPONSIBILITY FOR COLLECTION OF FEES:
   The leagues and organizations using the facilities shall be responsible for
the collection, reporting and paying to the parks department of the applicable
fee. (2000 Code § 11-622)
11-4B-3: REVIEW OF RATES:
   The park board shall be responsible for the annual review of the rate
schedule and shall report to the rate study committee of the city council prior
to April 1 of each year. (2000 Code § 11-623)
11-4B-4: PARK USER FEE FUND:
   All fees collected under this article shall be placed in a separate city
interest bearing account entitled "park user fee fund". All fees collected
herein shall be earmarked for maintenance and capital improvement of athletic
facilities. (2000 Code § 11-624)
11-4B-5: PENALTY:
   Anyone wilfully violating this article shall be guilty of an offense for
which the penalty shall be as provided in section 1-1-8 of this code, and
further may be denied use of the park facilities. (2000 Code § 11-625)
CHAPTER 5
SPORTSMAN LAKE
SECTION:
11-5-1: Permits And Rates For Facilities Use
11-5-2: Review Of Rates
11-5-3: Rules And Regulations
11-5-4: Penalty
11-5-1: PERMITS AND RATES FOR FACILITIES USE:
   A.   Fees Enumerated: The city is authorized and directed to collect the
following fees for Sportsman Lake facilities:
1.  Daily camping fees:
     Electric, water and sewage                           $20.00
     Electric and water only                              15.00
2.  Senior citizens camping (65 years of age and older):
     Electric, water and sewage                           17.00
     Electric and water only                              12.00
3.  Extra appliances                                      2.00
4.  Primitive camping                                     8.00
5.  Annual boat permit                                    25.00
6.  Daily boat permit                                     5.00
7.  Pavilion rental:
     a. Cove 3 - main campground                          25.00
     b. Cove 1 - equestrian campground (3 hours or less)  25.00
     c. Cove 1 - equestrian campground (daily)            75.00
8.  Building rental                                       50.00
9.  Equestrian camping                                    15.00
10. Equestrian senior citizens camping (65 or older)      12.00
11. Equestrian primitive camping                          8.00
12. Equestrian trail annual (immediate family)            30.00
13. Equestrian trail daily                                3.00
 
(Ord. 1156, 5-20-2013)
   B.   Possession Of Permit Required: Permits must be carried at all times
while on the lake. (Ord. 957, 6-10-2003)
11-5-2: REVIEW OF RATES:
   The lake development commission shall be responsible for the annual review
of the rate schedule and shall report to the rate study committee of the city
council prior to April 1 of each year. (Ord. 957, 6-10-2003; amd. Ord. 1068, 1-
8-2008, eff. 2-7-2008)
11-5-3: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   A.   Entire Lake Area: The rules cited in this subsection pertain to entire
Sportsman Lake area.
      1.   Payment of camping fee is required within thirty (30) minutes after
choosing a site.
      2.   All vehicle tires must be on the paved spur or on the graveled
camping area.
      3.   A person may not "hold" sites for other people even if payment is
made for the sites. Each site must be occupied by the person paying the fee and
must be occupied the first night and every day after.
      4.   No firearms or hunting is permitted.
      5.   Maximum camping is fifteen (15) days.
      6.   All dogs must be leashed or under owner's control at all times.
      7.   Campsites must be kept clean.
      8.   Campfires are allowed in designated areas only.
      9.   No alcoholic beverages (of any kind) are allowed.
      10.   No motor driven vehicles are permitted off the permanent roads or
adjacent parking areas.
      11.   The speed limit must be observed at all times.
      12.   No person shall deface any park property, or remove or misuse such
property in any improper way.
      13.   No person shall climb, cut or damage trees, shrubs or greenery in
the park area.
      14.   No person shall commit any nuisance or any offense against decency
or good morals in the park.
      15.   No person shall throw stones or rubbish of any kind into the lake
or upon the ground within the park area.
      16.   No person is authorized to sell any item from a vehicle, stand or
device without approval of the mayor and city council.
      17.   Overnight camping shall be in designated areas only, unless
authorized by the lake ranger.
      18.   No bicycles are allowed on equestrian or hiking trails. Bicycles
shall be on roads only. (Ord. 957, 6-10-2003)
   B.   Lake And Lake Camping Areas: Rules cited in this subsection pertain
specifically to lake and lake camping areas, in addition to rules cited in
subsection A of this section.
      1.   Swimming and wading is allowed in designated areas. No skiing or
seining is allowed. No person shall enter the water except in fishing
paraphernalia outside of designated swimming areas.
      2.   There shall be no trotlines or jug fishing. (Limb lines are
permitted only from existing tree limbs.)
      3.   There shall be no net type fishing including gill net, trammel net
or hoop net. (Ord. 992, 4-12-2005)
      4.   All largemouth bass less than twelve inches (12") in length must be
returned to the lake when caught. Spotted bass of any size may be kept. (Ord.
996, 5-10-2005)
      5.   Wheelchair vehicles shall be permitted on the pier; no cycles or
bikes are allowed. (Ord. 992, 4-12-2005)
      6.   No jet skis, wave runners, wet bikes or similar personal motorized
watercraft are allowed. (Ord. 1053, 3-13-2007)
