shall be exempt from this section. (Ord. 1144, 4-10-2012)
CHAPTER 2
WATER DEPARTMENT AND SERVICES
SECTION:
17-2-1: Water System As Public Utility
17-2-2: Water Rates
17-2-3: Application For Water Service
17-2-4: All Property To Be Connected With Water System
17-2-5: Individual Water Wells
17-2-1: WATER SYSTEM AS PUBLIC UTILITY:
   The water system of the City is hereby declared to be a public utility and a
proper source of City revenues and expenditures for the upkeep and maintenance
of the water system. (2000 Code § 17-201)
17-2-2: WATER RATES:
   A.   Fees And Charges Set By Council: The City Council shall from time to
time, with the approval of the Seminole Utility Authority, by ordinance, amend
the fees and charges for water use by customers of the City water system. A
copy of the current fees or charges shall be kept on file in the Office of the
City Clerk. (2000 Code § 17-202; amd. Ord. 1081, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-8-2008)
   B.   Rates Enumerated: Effective July 14, 2015, water rates to consumers
thereof within the City are established as follows:
      1.   Rates:
 
For the first 1,000 gallons or fractional part thereof $13.20
Over 1,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons                  3.20
Users of over 500,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons       2.35
 
      2.   Automatic Annual Rate Increase: An automatic five percent (5%)
increase shall be assessed to the rates each year commencing as of January 1,
2012, unless deferred by resolution. (Ord. 1192, 4-12-2016, eff. 4-12-2016)
      3.   Multi-Unit Family Dwellings, Computation Of Rates: Provided,
however, water rates and charges for multi-unit family dwellings on a master
meter shall be computed as follows:
   By each unit of a multi-unit family dwelling being charged under the above
schedule with an average water consumption per unit, with the total of the
average water consumption per unit charges added to arrive at a total figure.
The average water consumption per unit figure shall be calculated by dividing
the total amount of water used for the billing period by eighty percent (80%)
of the total number of units in the multi-unit family dwelling where the
occupancy has a water consumption per unit figure shall be calculated by
dividing the total amount of water used for the billing period by the total
number of units. "Multi-unit family dwelling" shall be defined as including,
but not limited to, apartment complexes, triplexes, duplexes, rental homes, and
mobile home parks. (Ord. 1043, 9-26-2006, eff. 9-26-2006)
17-2-3: APPLICATION FOR WATER SERVICE:
   Any person desiring to secure water from the City water system shall make an
application therefor to the Director of Public Works or his designee on an
application form to be provided by the City Clerk. The applicant shall give
such reasonable information as the Director of Public Works may request. He
shall state in the application that he will abide by all ordinances, rules and
regulations governing the water system of the City. (2000 Code § 17-203; amd.
Ord. 1081, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-8-2008)
17-2-4: ALL PROPERTY TO BE CONNECTED WITH WATER SYSTEM:
Every owner of property within the Municipal Limits having thereon any building
for human habitation, and within one quarter of a mile (1,320 feet) of a water
main of the City water system, or for any other purpose requiring the us of
water, shall, before the same is occupied or used, connect same with the water
system of the City, and shall prepare and fit same so that the water of the
City may be used thereon. (Ord. 1180, 2-9-2016)
17-2-5: INDIVIDUAL WATER WELLS:
   A.   No person shall drill or enlarge any water well, or subsequently use
the water from such well, except upon:
      1.   Application for a permit for such activity or usage from the
Community Development Department;
      2.   Payment of a one hundred dollars ($100.00) permit fee; and
      3.   Compliance with this Code and the rules and regulations of the
Oklahoma Department of Health, Department of Environmental Quality and Oklahoma
Water Resources Board.
   B.   Water from such wells shall be used only for agricultural purposes on
the premises where the well is located, and there shall be no interconnections
of any kind between such well and the water supply of the City. Any non-
agricultural usage existing before March 1, 2016, may be continued to the same
extent and for the same purposes, but such uses shall not be extended or
increased. For purposes of this section "agricultural purposes" shall be
defined as the raising of crops and other vegetation for use or consumption, as
well as the rearing of domestic animals.
   C.   All wells drilled, deepened or completed are subject to inspection and
regulation of the City, and the operation of such wells is subject to
inspection and regulation of the City, so as to prevent pollution and/or damage
to all water producing sands.
   D.   Wells may be located anywhere on the property owner's premises;
however, any well located outside of the rear areas of the premises may have
only the wellhead exposed with no other accompanying structure, pursuant to the
applicable zoning code of the City. No well may be drilled on an existing
easement or right-of-way.
   E.   All drilling mud must be removed manually and disposed of in accordance
with established laws and regulations. Under no circumstances may drilling mud
escape the property other than for property disposal as set forth herein.
   F.   Should the City subsequently furnish water services to users of private
water wells drawing water for household and/or commercial purposes, those
persons owning such wells shall within 60 days connect to the public water
supply. In such event, well water may continue being utilized for irrigation
purposes, swimming pools, and other purposes not inconsistent with these
provisions. (Ord. 1180, 2-9-2016)
CHAPTER 3
SEWER SYSTEM AND SERVICES
ARTICLE A. GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
17-3A-1: Sewer System As Public Utility
17-3A-2: Rates
17-3A-3: Facilities Required
17-3A-4: Definitions
17-3A-5: Connections Within And Without City Limits
17-3A-6: Septic Tank Requirements, Rules Adopted
17-3A-7: Sewage Facility; Violation; Penalty
17-3A-8: Prohibited Discharges Designated
17-3A-9: Prohibited Discharges; Violation; Penalty
17-3A-10: New Sewers And Connections
17-3A-11: Septage Hauler Permits And Fees; Landfill Leachate
17-3A-1: SEWER SYSTEM AS PUBLIC UTILITY:
   The sewer system of the City is hereby declared to be a public utility and a
proper source of City revenues and expenditures for the upkeep and maintenance
of the sewer system. (2000 Code § 17-301)
17-3A-2: RATES:
   A.   Rates Established:
      1.   Rates Enumerated: Effective July 14, 2015, rates for usage of the
Municipally owned wastewater treatment system shall be established as follows:
 
For up to 999 gallons of metered water consumption                       $14.05
For 1,000 gallons up to 500,000 gallons of metered water consumption or
increment thereof, there will be an additional charge per thousand       2.35
gallons of
For above 500,000 gallons of metered water consumption, there will be an 2.10
additional charge per thousand gallons of
 
   In the case of users not on a metered basis, the Director of Public Works
shall establish estimated water consumption based on a comparison of the non-
metered user with a metered use of similar class. Example: A non-metered family
of four (4) will be compared to a typical family of four (4) with a water meter
to establish water consumption.
      2.   Automatic Annual Rate Increase: An automatic five percent (5%)
increase shall be assessed to the established rates each year commencing as of
January 1, 2012, unless deferred by resolution. (Ord. 1193, 4-12-2016, eff. 4-
12-2016)
      3.   Exception To Established Rates: Exceptions to sewer rates for
certain industries, such as water bottling companies, shall be in effect. These
rates shall be as follows:
         a.   Sewer rates for excepted industries shall mirror Oklahoma
Department of Environmental Quality standards of one hundred thirty five (135)
gallons per day per employee. A base rate for ten (10) or less employees shall
be seventy five dollars ($75.00) per month. At any time there is an increase in
employment, the company shall be invoiced the base rate plus a sewer rate equal
to one hundred thirty five (135) gallons per day per employee for all but the
first ten (10) employees.
         b.   As an alternate, the industry may elect to purchase and install,
at their expense, an effluent flow meter and be billed for the exact gallons.
The meter shall be calibrated each year at the owner's expense. (Ord. 1202, 4-
11-2017)
   B.   Formula For Volume Basis Charges: As the biochemical oxygen demand
(BOD), suspended solids, and other pollutant concentrations discharged shall be
approximately equal for all domestic users, users shall be charged on a volume
basis in accordance with the following formula:
 
Cu = Cb + Ct/Vt(Vu)
Symbols And Definitions:
Cu = A user's charge per unit of time
Cb = A user's base minimum charge (for fixed operation and maintenance costs)
     per unit of time
Ct = Variable operation and maintenance (O&M) costs per unit of time
Vt = Total volume contribution from all users per unit of time (may include
     extraneous flows)
Vu = Volume contribution from a user per unit of time
 
   C.   Surcharge Formula: For any user, when BOD exceeds three hundred
milligrams per liter (300 mg/L) 1 , the suspended solids exceed three hundred
milligrams per liter (300 mg/L), or when other pollutant concentrations exceed
the range of concentrations of these pollutants in normal domestic sewage, a
surcharge shall be added to the basic charge. This surcharge shall be
calculated by the following formula:
C s = (Bc (B) + Sc (S) + Pc (P)) Vu
Symbols And Definitions:
Cs  = A surcharge for wastewaters of excessive strength
Bc  = Variable O&M cost for treatment of a unit of biochemical oxygen demand
      (BOD) = $0.035 per pound per day (calculated December 1988)
B   = Concentration of BOD from the user above a base level of 300 mg/l
Sc  = Variable O&M cost for treatment of unit of suspended solids (SS) = $0.07
      per mg/l per day (calculated December 1988)
S   = Concentration of 55 from a user above the base level of 300 mg/l
Pc  = Variable O&M cost for treatment of a unit of any pollutant
P   = Concentration of any pollutant from a user above a base level
Vu  = Volume contribution from a user per unit of time
 
   D.   User Charges, Periodic Review: The user charges shall be reviewed not
less often than every two (2) years regarding the wastewater contribution of
users and user classes, the total costs of the operation and maintenance and
replacement of the treatment works, and its approved user charge schedule. The
charges for users or user classes shall be revised to accomplish the following:
      1.   Maintain the proportionate distribution of operation and maintenance
costs among users and user classes;
      2.   Generate sufficient revenue to pay the total operation and
maintenance and replacement costs necessary for the proper operation and
maintenance (including replacement) of the treatment works; and
      3.   Apply excess revenues collected from a class of users to the costs
of operation and maintenance attributable to that class for the next year, and
the rates shall be adjusted accordingly.
   E.   Toxic Pollutants; Payment Of Increased Costs: Each user that discharges
any toxic pollutants which cause an increase in the cost of managing the
effluent or the sludge of the treatment works shall pay for such increased
costs.
   F.   Notification Of Charges For Wastewater Treatment: Each user shall be
notified at least annually, in conjunction with the regular bill, of the sewer
use rate and the portion of the user charges which are attributable to
wastewater treatment services. Costs shall be broken down to show the operation
and maintenance costs attributable to that user.
   G.   Infiltration And Inflow Charges: The cost of operation and maintenance
for all flows not directly attributable to users (such as infiltration/inflow)
shall be distributed among users on the same basis as operation and maintenance
charges.
   H.   Financial Management System: A financial management system shall be
established and maintained by the utility office of the city to document
compliance with federal regulations pertaining to user charges. The system will
account for all revenues generated and expenditures for operation and
maintenance and replacement.
   I.   User Charge System, Precedence: The user charge system shall take
precedence over any terms or conditions of agreements or contracts between the
city and any of the users which are inconsistent with applicable federal
regulations regarding user charge systems.
   J.   Monthly Billings; Delinquencies:
      1.   Users will be billed on a monthly basis with payment due on the
tenth of the month. Users on metered water service will be billed on the same
notice as water charges and will be designated as a separate entry. Users of
the wastewater system not on metered water service will be billed monthly on an
individual notice for wastewater service at a rate established by the director
of public works.
      2.   Users with delinquent accounts of five (5) days will be notified in
writing by the director of public works or his designee that water or
wastewater services will be terminated unless the account is paid in full.
      3.   The director of public works or his designee will utilize the law
enforcement agency to assist as required in the control and management of the
user charge system. (2000 Code § 17-302; amd. Ord. 1081, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-8-
2008)
 
Notes
1 1. Maximum limit for average domestic waste.
17-3A-3: FACILITIES REQUIRED 1 :
A. Requirement: Every residence and building in which humans reside or are
employed or congregate shall be required to have a sanitary method for the
disposal of human excreta. The toilets required by this article shall be the
sanitary water closet type when located within two hundred fifty feet (250') of
a sanitary sewer, and accessible thereto, and the sanitary pit privy type when
not so located.
   B.   Costs Borne By Owner: The cost of the provision of such facilities
shall be borne by the owner of the property. (2000 Code § 17-303)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 8-2-17 of this code, and subsection 17-3A-10C of this
  article.
17-3A-4: DEFINITIONS:
   Whenever the following words or terms are used in this article, they shall
have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
   DOMESTIC SEWAGE: Only human excreta and other such wastes which shall not be
harmful or injurious to the city sewage system, and specifically excluding all
salt water, chemicals or other substances which may be harmful to the system.
   SANITARY PIT PRIVY: A privy which is built, rebuilt or constructed so as to
conform to the specifications approved by the state health department.
   SANITARY WATER CLOSET: The flush type toilet which is connected with a sewer
line of sufficient capacity and so constructed as to carry away the contents at
all times. (2000 Code § 17-304)
17-3A-5: CONNECTIONS WITHIN AND WITHOUT CITY LIMITS:
   A.   Right To Construct: A person or group of individuals, corporation or
firm owning or occupying property within the city limits or within five (5)
miles of the city limits shall have the right to construct, at its or their own
proper expense, connections with the sewer system of the city, for the disposal
of domestic sewage under the restrictions and regulations hereafter set forth,
all as authorized by applicable law or ordinance.
   B.   State And City Approval Required: All private sewer connections made
with the city sewage disposal system may only be made after the approval of the
plan or plans of such connections by the state board of health and the city
engineer.
   C.   Fee: A fee shall be paid for each unit connection; provided, that the
term "unit connection" means a residence, an office, a workshop, a warehouse or
a store building. (2000 Code § 17-305)
   D.   Enforcement Official: The director of public works shall be advised as
to the addition or removal of any and all such unit connections, and payment of
the fee shall be made to the director of public works. (2000 Code § 17-305;
amd. Ord. 1081, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-8-2008)
17-3A-6: SEPTIC TANK REQUIREMENTS, RULES ADOPTED:
   Septic tanks may be used for the disposal of human and domestic waste within
the city limits only if the same are built and constructed according to
specifications as provided by the sanitary department of the city and the state
board of health, and the regulations of these departments. The city hereby
adopts and incorporates herein by reference title 252 of the Oklahoma
administrative code, chapter 641, "Individual And Small Public On-Site Sewage
Treatment Systems", the most recent edition thereof, to govern private sewage
disposal systems. (2000 Code § 17-306; amd. Ord. 1081, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-8-2008)
17-3A-7: SEWAGE FACILITY; VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   Any person who violates any provision of this article, either by doing that
which is prohibited or by failing or refusing to do that which is commanded, is
guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as
provided in section 1-1-8 of this code. (2000 Code § 17-307)
17-3A-8: PROHIBITED DISCHARGES DESIGNATED 1 :
A. Injurious Discharges: No person may discharge to public sewers any waste
which by itself or by interaction with other wastes may:
      1.   Injure or interfere with wastewater treatment processes or
facilities;
      2.   Constitute a hazard to humans or animals; or
      3.   Create a hazard in receiving waters of the wastewater treatment
plant effluent.
   B.   Discharges Allowed: All discharges shall be prohibited except those
that meet the criteria for "domestic wastewater". Biochemical oxygen demand
concentration shall not exceed three hundred milligrams per liter (300 mg/l),
unless approved by the city council. Suspended solids shall not exceed three
hundred milligrams per liter (300 mg/l).
   C.   Industrial Discharges, Toxic Pollutants; Surcharge:
      1.   All industrial discharges of toxic pollutants are prohibited.
Industrial wastewater which exceeds the limits for "domestic wastewater", as
defined above, shall be pretreated to reduce its concentration to that of
domestic wastewater prior to discharge to the sanitary sewer system.
      2.   The city may, at its option, require the industry to pay a surcharge
for excessive strength wastewater in lieu of pretreatment of the excessive
strength wastewater. The surcharge shall be based upon excessive strength
charges as shown in subsection 17-3A-2D of this article, "user charges".
      3.   In no case shall the industrial discharge interfere with the
wastewater treatment processes or facilities nor shall the industrial discharge
create a hazard in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant
effluent.
   D.   New Connections: Any new connections from inflow sources into the
sanitary sewer portions of the sewer system shall be prohibited.
   E.   Prohibited Substances: No person shall discharge or cause to be
discharged the following substances if it appears likely, in the opinion of the
superintendent of water and sewage treatment, that such wastes can harm the
sewers, the sewage treatment process or equipment; have an adverse effect on
the receiving stream; or can otherwise endanger life, limb, or public property,
or otherwise constitute a nuisance. The prohibited substances are:
      1.   Flammable or explosive materials.
      2.   Water or wastes containing fats, wax, grease or oil in excess of one
hundred milligrams per liter (100 mg/l), or containing any substance which may
solidify or become viscous at temperatures higher than thirty two degrees
Fahrenheit (32°F).
      3.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred
fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F).
      4.   Any garbage or food waste not properly shredded. The installation
and operation of any grinder or shredder equipped with a motor of three-fourths
(3/4) horsepower or greater shall be subject to review and approval by the
superintendent of water and sewage treatment.
      5.   Any waters or wastes containing the metals listed below or other
toxic substances in quantities determined by the superintendent of water and
sewage treatment to be harmful:
   Antimony
   Arsenic
   Barium
   Beryllium
   Bismuth
   Boron
   Cadmium
   Chromium
   Cobalt
   Copper
   Iron
   Lead
   Manganese
   Mercury
   Molybdenum
   Nickel
   Rhenium
   Selenium
   Silver
   Strontium
   Tellurium
   Tin
   Uranium
   Zinc
      6.   Any water or waste containing iron pickling wastes or plating
solutions.
      7.   Any water or waste containing phenols or other taste or odor
producing substances. (2000 Code § 17-308)
      8.   Any radioactive wastes of a half-life or concentration determined by
the superintendent of water and sewage treatment to be harmful.
      9.   Any water or wastes having pH lower than 5.5, or having a pH higher
than 9.5, or having any corrosive property capable of damaging installations,
equipment or personnel of the sewerage works.
      10.   Solid or viscous substances of such size or in such quantities
capable of causing obstruction of sewers or interference with operation of
sewage works, such as ashes, cinders, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags,
feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure,
hair fleshings, entrails and paper containers.
      11.   Wastes containing unusual concentrations of suspended solids, such
as fuller's earth, lime or clay.
      12.   Wastes containing unusual concentrations of dissolved substances,
such as sodium chloride or sodium sulfate.
      13.   Wastes containing unusual concentrations of organic material, such
as whey, milk, yeast, blood, or unusual biochemical oxygen demand (BOD),
chemical oxygen demand (COD), or chlorine requirement, constituting a
significant load on the sewage treatment facilities.
      14.   Material which causes unusual volume of flow or concentration of
wastes constituting slugs which adversely affect the sewage treatment process.
   F.   Enforcement Actions Of City; Application For Permit:
      1.   If any waters or wastes are discharged or proposed to be discharged,
or if, in the opinion of the director of public works, might be accidentally
discharged, which contain the substances described above, the director of
public works may prohibit their discharge; may require the establishment to
alter or initially construct its facilities so that accidental discharges may
not occur; require the responsible party to pretreat the wastes before
discharge; limit the quantity, rates and times of discharge; require the
installation of a control manhole for observation, sampling and metering of the
wastes; and assess a surcharge based on the quantity and strength of the
wastes.
      2.   If pretreatment is to be accomplished, the design, installation and
operation of the plant and equipment shall be subject to the review and
approval of the director of public works or his designee.
      3.   Applications for permits for sewer connections for industrial wastes
shall show the following information:
         a.   A plat of the property showing all existing sewers and storm
drains;
         b.   Plans and specifications covering any work proposed to be done
under the permit;
         c.   A schedule of all process waters and industrial wastes produced
or to be produced, a description of the character of such waste, the daily
volume and maximum rates of discharge and representative analysis; and
         d.   The name of the firm or person who will perform the work covered
by the application.
   G.   Notice Of Nonconformance; Failure To Remedy: The director of public
works shall cause to be served on the owner or occupant of any establishment
having sewer connections which do not conform to the provisions hereof at the
time of the effective date hereof, a notice in writing advising that
requirements must be met within one hundred twenty (120) days. If after one
hundred twenty (120) days from the day of service of the notice, the proper
measures have not been taken, enforcement action may be initiated as set forth
elsewhere in this article.
   H.   Periodic Testing Of Samples Of Wastes: The director of public works or
his designee shall cause samples of wastes from industrial establishments to be
obtained and tested periodically, to determine the quantity and composition
thereof. Standards adopted by the state department of health will be used to
determine action by the director. (2000 Code § 17-308; amd. Ord. 1081, 4-8-
2008, eff. 5-8-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 17-3B-2 of this chapter.
17-3A-9: PROHIBITED DISCHARGES; VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Misdemeanor; Penalty: Any person, firm or corporation who continues any
violation beyond the time limit provided for in this article is guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in
section 1-1-8 of this code for each act of violation and for each day of
violation.
   B.   Other Criminal And Civil Remedies: In addition to proceeding under
authority of subsection A of this section, the city is entitled to pursue all
other criminal and civil remedies to which it is entitled under authority of
statutes or other ordinances against a person continuing prohibited discharges.
   C.   Termination Of Service: The city reserves the right to terminate
service to any customer that fails to pay bills when due or discharges any
prohibited wastes into the sewer system. (2000 Code § 17-309)
17-3A-10: NEW SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Connection; Compliance With Building Code: The connection of the
building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the
building code as currently adopted by the city and other applicable rules and
regulations of the city. (2000 Code § 17-310; amd. Ord. 1081, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-
8-2008)
   B.   Design And Construction; Compliance With State Regulations: All new
sanitary sewage works shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the
requirements of the Oklahoma state department of health regulations.
   C.   Mandatory Connection To Public Sewer: The building sewer within two
hundred fifty feet (250') of the public sewer shall be connected to the public
sewer as indicated below 1 :
      1.   A newly constructed building shall connect immediately;
      2.   Existing buildings, not previously on the public sewer, which are
being remodeled such that an increase in wastewater flow is expected shall
connect to the public sewer within one hundred eighty (180) days;
      3.   Existing buildings, not previously on the public sewer, which are
experiencing problems with their septic tank or lateral lines shall connect
within one hundred eighty (180) days in lieu of repairing the private sewer
system; or
      4.   Existing buildings, not previously on the public sewer, which have
been deemed to constitute a public health nuisance by appropriate health
officials shall connect within one hundred eighty (180) days of notification.
      5.   Existing buildings with private sewer systems which are functioning
properly shall not be required to connect to the public sewer. (2000 Code § 17-
310)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 8-2-17 of this code, and subsection 17-3A-3A of this
  article.
17-3A-11: SEPTAGE HAULER PERMITS AND FEES; LANDFILL LEACHATE:
   A.   Permit Application:
      1.   A septage hauler who holds a current license through Oklahoma
department of environmental quality may apply for a permit through the public
works department to use the Seminole wastewater treatment plant to dispose of
septage.
      2.   The issued permit shall be valid from July 1 through June 30.
   B.   Permit Fees: Nonrefundable permit fees shall be implemented as follows:
 
Gallons          Fee
   0 - 1,250  $ 750.00
   1,250 - 2,51,500.00
   Over 2,500 2,500.00
 
   C.   Violations, Revocation: Any permit under this section may be revoked if
any city, state or federal laws or ordinances are violated.
   D.   Landfill Leachate:
      1.   Allowable: The Seminole wastewater treatment plant may allow
leachate from area landfills. It shall be analyzed by a state certified
laboratory prior to disposal at the wastewater treatment plant, with a report
given to the plant supervisor before disposal.
      2.   Leachate Fees: Nonrefundable fees shall be two dollars ($2.00) per
barrel. (Ord. 1179, 9-8-2015)
ARTICLE B. INDUSTRIAL WASTE REGULATIONS
SECTION:
17-3B-1: Definitions
17-3B-2: Use Of Public Sewers; Prohibited Discharges
17-3B-3: Actions Of City Regarding Prohibited Discharges
17-3B-4: Grease, Oil And Sand Traps
17-3B-5: Preliminary Treatment And Flow Equalizing
17-3B-6: Control Manhole Required
17-3B-7: Measurements And Tests
17-3B-8: Special Agreements
17-3B-9: Payment For Industrial Waste Discharges
17-3B-10: Permit For Discharge Of Industrial Waste
17-3B-11: Penalty For Damage
17-3B-12: Powers And Authority Of Inspectors
17-3B-13: Authority To Disconnect Service
17-3B-14: Penalties
17-3B-1: DEFINITIONS:
   The following terms, as used in this article, shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this section:
   APPROVING AUTHORITY: The chief executive or his duly authorized
representative.
   BOD (BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND): The quantity of oxygen by weight, expressed
in mg/l, utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard
laboratory conditions for five (5) days at a temperature of twenty degrees
centigrade (20°C).
   BUILDING DRAIN: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage
system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes
inside the walls of the building and conveys such wastes to the building sewer
beginning five feet (5') outside the inner face of the building wall.
   BUILDING SEWER: The extension from the building drain to the sewer or other
place of disposal (also called house lateral and house connection).
   COD (CHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND): A measure of the oxygen consuming capacity,
expressed in mg/l, of inorganic and organic matter present in water or
wastewater. It is expressed as the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical
oxidant in a specific test. It does not differentiate between stable and
unstable matter, and thus does not necessarily correlate with biochemical
oxygen demand.
   CITY: The city or any authorized person acting in its behalf.
   DOMESTIC WASTEWATER: Waterborne waste normally discharging into the sanitary
conveniences of dwellings (including apartment houses and hotels), office
buildings, factories, and institutions, which may or may not contain stormwater
and industrial wastes.
   GARBAGE: Animal and vegetable wastes and residue from the preparation,
cooking, and dispensing of food; and from the handling, processing, storage and
sale of food products and produce.
   INDUSTRIAL WASTE: Waterborne solids, liquids, or gaseous wastes resulting
from and discharged, permitted to flow, or escaping from the industrial,
manufacturing, or food processing operation or process, or from the development
of any natural resource, or any mixture of these with water or domestic
wastewater, or distinct from normal domestic wastewater.
   INDUSTRIAL WASTE CHARGE: The charge made on those persons who discharge
industrial wastes into the city's sewerage system.
   MILLIGRAMS PER LITER (mg/l): The same as parts per million and is a weight
to weight volume ratio; the milligram per liter value multiplied by the factor
8.34 shall be equivalent to pounds per million gallons of water.
   NATURAL OUTLET: Any outlet into a watercourse, ditch, lake, or other body of
surface or ground water.
   NORMAL DOMESTIC WASTEWATER: Normal wastewater for the city in which the
average concentration of suspended solids and five (5) day BOD is established
at not more than two hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l).
   PERSON: Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any
individual, firm, company, industry, municipal or private corporation,
association, governmental agency, or other entity, and agents, servants, or
employees.
   pH: The reciprocal of the logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion
concentration expressed in grams per liter.
   PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE: The wastes from the preparation, cooking, and
dispensing of food that have been shredded to such degree that all particles
shall be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public
sewers, with no particles greater than one-half inch (1/2") in any dimension.
   PUBLIC SEWER: A sewer in which all owners of abutting properties shall have
equal rights and the use of which is controlled by public authority.
   SANITARY SEWER: A sewer that conveys domestic wastewater or wastes or a
combination of both, and into which storm, surface and ground unpolluted wastes
are not intentionally passed.
   SEWER: A pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water.
   SLUG: Any discharge of water, wastewater, or industrial waste which, in
concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any
period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times
the average twenty four (24) hour concentration or flows during normal
operation.
   STANDARD ANALYSIS METHODS: The examination and analytical procedures set
forth in the latest edition at the time of analysis of "Methods For Chemical
Analysis Of Water And Wastes" as prepared by the environmental protection
agency's water quality control laboratory, Cincinnati, Ohio.
   STORM SEWER OR STORM DRAIN: A sewer which carries storm and surface waters
and drainage but excludes domestic wastewater and polluted industrial wastes.
   STORMWATER: Rainfall or any other form of precipitation.
   SUSPENDED SOLIDS: Solids that either float on the surface of, or in water,
wastewater, or other liquids, and which are largely removable by a filtration
device.
   UNPOLLUTED WATER OR WASTE: Water or waste containing none of the following:
free or emulsified grease or oil; acids or alkalis, phenols, or other
substances producing taste or odor in receiving water; toxic or poisonous
substances in suspension, colloidal state or solution; and noxious or otherwise
obnoxious, odorous gases. It shall contain not more than ten milligrams per
liter (10 mg/l) each of suspended solids and BOD. The color shall not exceed
twenty (20) color units as measured by the platinum-cobalt method of
determination as specified in standard analysis methods.
   WASTEWATER: A combination of the water carried waste from residences,
business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments; together with
such ground, surface and storm water that may be present.
   WASTEWATER FACILITIES: All facilities for collection, pumping, treating and
disposing of wastewater and industrial wastes.
   WASTEWATER SERVICE CHARGE: The charge on all users of the public sewer
system whose wastes do not exceed in strength the concentration values
established as representative of normal wastewater.
   WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT: All facilities for collection, pumping,
treatment and all city owned facilities, devices and structures used for
receiving wastewater, industrial waste, and sludges from the city wastewater
facility.
   WATERCOURSE: A natural or manmade channel in which a flow of water occurs,
either continuously or intermittently. (2000 Code § 17-321; amd. Ord. 1081, 4-
8-2008, eff. 5-8-2008)
17-3B-2: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS; PROHIBITED DISCHARGES 1 :
   A.   Prohibited Discharges Enumerated: No person shall discharge or cause to
be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public
sewers:
      1.   Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or
explosive liquid, solid or gas.
      2.   Any stormwater, surface water, ground water, roof runoff, subsurface
drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters
to any sanitary sewer. Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be
discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or
storm sewers, or to a natural watercourse approved by the approving authority.
Industrial cooling water may be discharged, on approval of the approving
authority, to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural watercourse.
      3.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred
fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) or any discharge which causes the temperature
of the total wastewater treatment plant influent to increase at a rate of ten
degrees Fahrenheit (10°F) or more per hour, or a combined total increase to a
plant influent temperature of one hundred ten degrees Fahrenheit (110°F).
      4.   Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease or oils, whether
emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred milligrams per liter (100 mg/l) or
containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures
between thirty two degrees Fahrenheit (32°F) and one hundred fifty degrees
Fahrenheit (150°F) (0 to 65 degrees centigrade).
      5.   Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation
and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/
4) horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and
approval of the approving authority.
      6.   Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes,
or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not.
      7.   Any waters or wastes containing objectionable or toxic, or poisonous
substances, or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such
degree that any such material received in the composite wastewater at the
wastewater treatment works exceeds the limits established by the approving
authority for such materials.
      8.   Any waters or wastes containing obnoxious, toxic, or poisonous
solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by
interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any wastewater
treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or create any
hazard in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant, including,
but not limited to:
         a.   Any cyanide greater than 0.0100 mg/l.
         b.   Any fluoride other than that contained in the public water
supply.
         c.   Concentrations of the following greater than the mg/l amounts
indicated, to be measured at the point of discharge to the sewer line:
Element        Milligrams Per Liter
                        (mg/l)
Element        Milligrams Per Liter
                        (mg/l)
Aluminum                   1.0000
Arsenic                    0.0500
Barium                     5.0000
Boron                      1.0000
Cadmium                    0.0200
Chromium (Hexa)            0.0500
Chromium (Tri)             5.0000
Copper                     0.1000
Iron                       0.3000
Lead                       0.1000
Manganese                  1.000
Mercury                    0.0050
Nickel                     1.000
Phenol                     0.0050
Selenium                   0.0200
Silver                     0.1000
Zinc                       1.000
 
         d.   Water or wastes which cause concentrations of the following
parameters such as: total dissolved solids, chlorides, alkalinity, and sulfates
in excess of twenty percent (20%) of the amount normally present in the raw
water supply; these concentrations to be measured at the point of discharge
into the sewer line.
         e.   All other heavy metals and toxic substances, including, but not
limited to, the following, shall be excluded from the wastewater system unless
a permit specifying the conditions of pretreatment, concentrations, volumes,
etc., is obtained from the city: antimony, beryllium, cobalt, molybdenum, tin,
uranylion, pesticides, rhenium, strontium, tellurium, herbicides, fungicides;
and any substance causing an excessive chemical oxygen demand, of greater than
five hundred milligrams per liter (500 mg/l).
      9.   Any waters or wastes having pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.5,
having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to
structures, equipment and personnel at wastewater facilities.
      10.   Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable
of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the
proper operation of the wastewater works, such as, but not limited to, ashes,
cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar,
plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and
fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole
or ground by garbage grinders, lime slurry, lime residues, slops, chemical
residues, paint residues, or bulk solids.
      11.   Any waters or wastes containing phenols, hydrogen sulfide, or other
taste and odor producing substances, in such concentration exceeding limits
which may be established by the approving authority as necessary, after
treatment of composite wastewater, to meet the requirements of the state,
federal, or other public agencies having jurisdiction for such discharge to the
receiving waters.
      12.   Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or
concentrations as may exceed limits established by the approving authority, in
compliance with applicable state or federal regulations.
      13.   Materials which exert or cause:
         a.   Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids greater than two
hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l) (such as, but not limited to,
fuller's earth, lime slurries and lime residues) or of dissolved solids in
excess of twenty percent (20%) of that normally found in the raw water supply
(such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate).
         b.   Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes
and vegetable tanning solutions).
         c.   Unusual BOD (greater than the amount established in section 17-
3A-8 of this chapter), COD, or chlorine demand in such quantities as to
constitute a significant load on the wastewater treatment works.
         d.   Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting a
"slug" as defined in section 17-3B-1 of this article shall be regulated to
equalize the flow and/or concentration to levels acceptable to the city if such
waste can damage the collections facilities, impair the treatment process,
incur treatment costs exceeding those for normal wastewater, or render the
waste unfit for stream disposal and industrial use.
      14.   Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to
treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree
that the wastewater treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of
other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters.
      15.   Except in quantities or concentrations, or with provisions as
stipulated herein, it shall be unlawful for any person, corporation or
individual to discharge water or wastes to the sanitary sewer that:
         a.   Can deposit grease or oil in the sewer lines in such a manner as
to clog the sewers;
         b.   Can overload skimming and grease handling equipment;
         c.   Are not amenable to bacterial action, and will, therefore, pass
to the receiving waters without being affected by normal wastewater treatment
processes; or
         d.   Can have a deleterious effect on the treatment process due to
excessive quantities.
   B.   Mandatory Use Of Public Sewer System: The public sewer system will be
used, whenever such system is available, by all persons discharging any
wastewater, industrial waste, other polluted liquids, or unpolluted waters or
liquids, unless an exception is granted by the approving authority.
   C.   Wastewater Discharged On Public Or Private Property: No person shall
deposit or discharge any wastewater, industrial waste, other polluted waters or
liquids on public or private property, in or adjacent to any natural outlet or
any natural watercourse, or in any storm sewer within the city, or in any area
under the jurisdiction of the city, without approval of the approving
authority. In providing approval, the approving authority will verify that such
wastes will receive suitable treatment within the provisions of federal, state,
or local laws, regulations, and/or ordinances. (2000 Code § 17-322)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 17-3A-8 of this title.
17-3B-3: ACTIONS OF CITY REGARDING PROHIBITED DISCHARGES:
   A.   Actions Of City: If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are
proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which contain the substances or
possess the characteristics enumerated in section 17-3B-2 of this article, and
which, in the judgment of the approving authority, may have a deleterious
effect upon the wastewater works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or
which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a health hazard or public
nuisance, the approving authority may:
      1.   Reject the wastes;
      2.   Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the
public sewers;
      3.   Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; or
      4.   Require payment to cover the cost of handling and treating the
wastes under the provisions of article A of this chapter.
   B.   Design And Installation Subject To Review: If the approving authority
permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and
installation of the plant and equipment shall be subject to the review and
approval of the approving authority, and subject to the requirements of all
applicable codes, ordinances and laws.
   C.   Application: The approving authority will either apply subsection A1,
A2, A3 of this section and will apply subsection A4 of this section in all
cases. (2000 Code § 17-323)
17-3B-4: GREASE, OIL AND SAND TRAPS:
   Grease, oil, and sand traps shall be provided for the proper handling of
liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes,
sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such traps shall not be
required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All traps shall be of a
type and capacity approved by the approving authority, and shall be located as
to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. (2000 Code §
17-324)
17-3B-5: PRELIMINARY TREATMENT AND FLOW EQUALIZING:
   Where preliminary treatment or flow equalizing facilities are provided for
any wastes or waters, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and
effective operation by the owner at his expense. (2000 Code § 17-325)
17-3B-6: CONTROL MANHOLE REQUIRED:
   The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial
wastes shall install a suitable control manhole, together with such necessary
meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation,
sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be
accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with
plans approved by the approving authority. The manhole shall be installed by
the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and
accessible at all times. (2000 Code § 17-326)
17-3B-7: MEASUREMENTS AND TESTS:
   All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and
wastes to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of "Methods For Chemical Analysis Of Water
And Wastes", and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon
suitable samples taken at the manhole. Sampling shall be carried out by
customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the
sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to health, life, limb
and property. (The particular analyses involved will determine whether a 24
hour composite sample from all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether
a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and
suspended solids analyses are obtained from 24 hour composites of all outfalls,
whereas pHs are determined from periodic grab samples.) (2000 Code § 17-327)
17-3B-8: SPECIAL AGREEMENTS:
   No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any
special agreement or arrangement between the city and industrial concern
whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by
the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern,
as set forth in article A of this chapter; provided, that the waste control
order (discharge permits), Oklahoma department of environmental quality orders,
and other federal, state and local laws are not violated. (2000 Code § 17-328;
amd. Ord. 1081, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-8-2008)
17-3B-9: PAYMENT FOR INDUSTRIAL WASTE DISCHARGES:
   A.   Agreement Between City And Contributor: If the approving authority
determines that an industrial waste is acceptable under the discretionary
powers given him under this article, the contributor of the industrial waste
shall be required to make payment of a charge to cover the cost of handling and
treating the wastes. As permitted by this article, if the city accepts the
waste, the city and the industrial concern contributing the waste shall enter
into an arrangement or agreement whereby the city will accept the waste and the
industrial concern will make payment therefor by one of the methods set forth
in subsections B and C of this section.
   B.   Prepayment Of Costs: If the volume or character of the waste to be
accepted by the city is such that wastewater collection, pumping, handling,
treating, or disposal facilities of the city must be improved, expanded,
enlarged, or added to in order to take care of such waste, or where an
industrial user will contribute thirty percent (30%) or more of the total
volume or strength of the waste load to be treated, then the authority shall
enter into an agreement for prepayment from the contributor in accordance with
current federal requirements.
   C.   Added Costs: Added costs to the city shall include:
      1.   Amortization of all capital outlay for handling and treating the
waste, including new capital outlay and the proportionate part of the value of
the existing system used in handling and treating the waste. The amortization
shall be completed in a thirty (30) year period and payments shall include all
debt service costs.
      2.   All operation and maintenance costs including salaries and wages,
power costs, costs of chemicals and supplies, proper allowances for
maintenance, depreciation, overhead and office expense.
   D.   Calculation Of Industrial Charge, Formula; Billing: If the volume or
character of the waste to be accepted by the city is such that it will not
overload the sewage collection, pumping, handling, treating, or disposal
facilities of the city, then prior to such acceptance, the city and industrial
concern shall enter into an agreement whereby the industrial concern shall make
payment of an industrial waste charge to be determined as set forth below. The
industrial charge shall be calculated by the following formula:
      Ci = jVi +    Vi
         1,000   / Y (BOD-200) + Z (SS-200) /
   This formula is explained in attachment to ordinance 532, adopted herein by
reference:
      1.   BOD = 5 day BOD in mg/l and SS = suspended solids in mg/l, as
defined elsewhere, and shall be determined from a twenty four (24) hour
composite sample. The determination of flow, BOD, and suspended solids shall be
made by an independent firm or laboratory selected by the city. The time of
selection of the sample shall be at the sole discretion of the city, but at
least on an annual basis, to adjust the industrial charge to reflect the
current costs of wastewater treatment. The applicable surcharge determined by
such test shall be retroactive for two (2) billing periods and shall continue
for six (6) billing periods unless subsequent tests determine that the
surcharge should be further increased.
      2.   The basis for determining the surcharge shall be reviewed annually,
and shall be adjusted to reflect any increase or decrease in wastewater
treatment costs based on the previous year's experience.
      3.   Billing shall be by the month and shall be shown as a separate item
on the regular bill for water and sewer charges, and shall be paid monthly in
accordance with existing practices. (2000 Code § 17-329)
17-3B-10: PERMIT FOR DISCHARGE OF INDUSTRIAL WASTE:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall deposit or discharge any industrial
waste into any sanitary sewer which leads to any of the city treatment plants,
or deposit or discharge any waste stipulated in this article without first
obtaining a permit therefor in accordance with regulations as set forth by the
Oklahoma department of environmental quality. (2000 Code § 17-330; amd. Ord.
1081, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-8-2008)
   B.   Conditions For Issuance Of Permit: Permits granted after the effective
date hereof will be issued only after the following conditions are met:
      1.   New Dischargers:
         a.   Formal application is submitted on a form issued by the approving
authority as provided in attachment 2 to ordinance 532, incorporated herein by
reference.
         b.   Where applicable, pretreatment facilities and/or flow regulating
devices approved by the approving authority have been installed.
         c.   Estimated amount and strength of any wastes have been agreed upon
by both parties. When a discharger discharges twenty thousand (20,000) gallons
or more daily, strength shall be based on actual samples from the point or
points of discharge.
         d.   Agreement forms have been completed by the discharger agreeing to
payment of any surcharges as required, and/or agreeing to the installation of
pretreatment facilities, and operation and maintenance of any pretreatment
facilities where applicable.
         e.   All new dischargers shall provide a sampling point subject to
approval of the approving authority.
      2.   Existing Dischargers:
         a.   Formal application is submitted on a form issued by the approving
authority within one hundred twenty (120) days after the effective date hereof
as provided in attachment 2 to ordinance 532, incorporated herein by reference.
         b.   Where applicable, plans and specifications for pretreatment
facilities have been approved by the approving authority.
         c.   Estimated amount and strength of any wastes have been agreed upon
by both parties. When a discharger discharges twenty thousand (20,000) gallons
or more daily, strength shall be based on actual samples from the point or
points of discharge. (2000 Code § 17-330)
         d.   Agreement forms have been completed by the discharger agreeing to
payment of any surcharges as required and/or agreeing to the installation of
pretreatment facilities, and operation and maintenance of any pretreatment
facilities where applicable. (2000 Code § 17-330; amd. Ord. 1081, 4-8-2008,
eff. 5-8-2008)
17-3B-11: PENALTY FOR DAMAGE:
   It shall be unlawful for any person to maliciously, wilfully, or negligently
break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure,
appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the sewage works. Any person
violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of
disorderly conduct. (2000 Code § 17-331)
17-3B-12: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS:
   A.   Right Of Entry; Authority Restricted: The director of public works and
other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and
identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purpose of
inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with
the provisions of this article. The director of public works or his designated
representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes including
metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper, or other industries
beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge
to the sewers, waterways, or facilities for waste treatment.
   B.   Liability Of City And Company: While performing the necessary work on
private properties referred to in this article, the director of public works or
duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable
to the premises, established by the company, and the company shall be held
harmless for injury or death of the city employees; and the city shall
indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by city employees
and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage
asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and/or sampling
operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company
to maintain safe conditions as required in this article.
   C.   Entering Property Through Easements: The director of public works and
other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and
identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which
the city holds duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited
to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of
any portion of the sewage system lying within the easement. All entry and
subsequent work, if any, on the easement, shall be done in full accordance with
the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property
involved. (2000 Code § 17-332; amd. Ord. 1081, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-8-2008)
17-3B-13: AUTHORITY TO DISCONNECT SERVICE:
   In the following situations, the city shall retain the right to terminate
water and wastewater disposal service and immediately disconnect an industrial
customer from the system:
   A.   Where acids or chemicals damaging to sewer lines or treatment processes
are released to the sewer causing rapid deterioration of these structures or
interfering with proper conveyance and treatment of wastewater.
   B.   When the customer discharges industrial waste or wastewater that is in
violation of the permit issued by the approving authority.
   C.   Where any governmental agency informs the city that the effluent from
wastewater treatment plant is no longer of a quality permitted for discharge to
a watercourse, and it is found that a customer is delivering wastewater to the
city system that cannot be sufficiently treated or requires treatment that is
not provided by the city as normal domestic treatment. In this instance, the
city shall immediately supply the customer with the governmental agency's
report and provide the customer with all pertinent information. The customer's
water and wastewater lines will then be disconnected until such time as he has
provided additional pretreatment facilities designed to remove the
objectionable characteristics from his industrial water.
   D.   Where the owner delivers his wastewater at an uncontrolled, variable
rate in sufficient quantity that it causes an imbalance in the wastewater
treatment system. (2000 Code § 17-333)
17-3B-14: PENALTIES:
   A.   Notice Of Violation; Remedial Action: Any person found to be violating
any provision of this article shall be served by the city with written notice
stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for
the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of
time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations.
   B.   Continuing Violation; Penalty: Any person who shall continue any
violation beyond the time limit provided for in this article shall be deemed
guilty of a violation thereof and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined as
provided in section 1-1-8 of this code for each violation. Each day in which
any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense.
   C.   Liability For Damages: Any person violating any of the provisions of
this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage
occasioned the city by reason of such violation.
   D.   Discontinuance Of Service: Failure to pay monthly bills for water or
sanitary sewer services when due or failure to pay the established sewer
charges for industrial waste when due, or repeated discharge of prohibited
waste to the sanitary sewer shall result in disconnection of any and all
services to the water and/or sanitary sewer lines of the city. The same
penalties and charges now or hereafter provided for by the ordinances of the
city for failure to pay the bill for water and/or sanitary sewer service when
due shall be applicable in like manner in case of failure to pay the
established charge for industrial waste discharged to the sanitary sewer mains
as established in this article. (2000 Code § 17-334)
CHAPTER 4
GARBAGE SYSTEM
SECTION:
17-4-1: Definitions
17-4-2: Enforcement
17-4-3: Compulsory Use Of System
17-4-4: Refuse Collection Rates; Schedules
17-4-5: Refuse Collection; License Required
17-4-6: Accumulation Unlawful
17-4-7: Container Requirements
17-4-8: Commercial Refuse Collections; Containers; Fees
17-4-9: Mobile Containers Provided By City; Regulations
17-4-10: Licensing And Contracting Authority
17-4-11: Violation; Penalty
17-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
   Whenever the following words or terms are used in this chapter, they shall
have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
   COLLECTOR: The person holding a license or contract with the city and
authorized to collect, handle, transport and dispose of refuse and wastes.
   GARBAGE: Includes all putrescible waste, except sewage and body waste.
   OWNER AND OCCUPANT: Whenever herein used, may be used interchangeably and
such terms mean every person in possession, charge or in control of any
dwelling, flat, rooming house or any eating place, shop, place of business,
manufacturing or business establishment where garbage or other refuse is
created or accumulated.
   REFUSE: Solid wastes, including garbage and rubbish.
   RUBBISH: Refuse other than garbage.
   WASTE: Unwanted solid, liquid or gaseous materials. (2000 Code § 17-401)
17-4-2: ENFORCEMENT:
   The chief of police or his designee as may be appointed by the mayor and
council shall be responsible for the enforcement of the provisions of this
chapter. (2000 Code § 17-402; amd. Ord. 1081, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-8-2008)
17-4-3: COMPULSORY USE OF SYSTEM:
   Every owner and occupant of premises within the prescribed limits of the
city must use the refuse collection and disposal system herein provided and
shall deposit or cause to be deposited in accordance with this chapter all
rubbish and garbage that is of such nature that it is perishable, or may
decompose or may be scattered by wind or otherwise, which is accumulated on
such premises. (2000 Code § 17-403)
17-4-4: REFUSE COLLECTION RATES; SCHEDULES:
   The city council shall from time to time by ordinance or resolution set or
amend the fees and charges for refuse collection service by customers and the
time and schedule for collection. A copy of the current fees or charges and
schedule shall be kept on file in the city clerk's office. Fees and charges
shall be billed with the water statements and paid through the water department
office. (2000 Code § 17-404)
17-4-5: REFUSE COLLECTION; LICENSE REQUIRED:
   It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of collecting,
transporting, hauling or conveying any refuse over the streets or alleys of the
city or to dump or dispose of the same, unless and until such person is
licensed therefor or has a contract therefor as an authorized representative of
the city or has the direct consent and permission of the mayor or city health
officer. (2000 Code § 17-405)
17-4-6: ACCUMULATION UNLAWFUL:
   It is unlawful for any person to permit or to suffer to accumulate in or
about any yard, lot, place or premises, or upon any street, alley or sidewalk
adjacent to such lot, yard, place or premises, owned or occupied by such
person, any garbage or refuse. (2000 Code § 17-406)
17-4-7: CONTAINER REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Portable Containers Required: It shall be the duty of every owner or
occupant of any place where garbage or rubbish is created or accumulated to at
all times keep or cause to be kept portable containers as provided by the City
or its designated collector for the deposit therein of rubbish and garbage and,
except as otherwise provided, to deposit or cause to be deposited all rubbish
and garbage therein.
   B.   Sanitation; Placement Of Containers:
      1.   Such containers shall be kept in a sanitary condition, with the
inside and outside thereof washed at such time as to keep the same free and
clean of all accumulated grease and decomposing material and so that no odor
nuisance shall exist.
      2.   All garbage or refuse containers shall be placed in a place
accessible to the collector.
   C.   Business Establishments: All mercantile houses, commercial houses and
public places of business shall be provided by the City or its designated
collector with containers in which the mercantile house, commercial houses or
public places of business within the City shall deposit all trash, waste
material or garbage to be picked up by the Garbage Department of the City or
its designated collector. The capacity and dimensions or size of the containers
for the deposit of the garbage by the owner or operator of the business, either
mercantile, commercial or public, shall be determined by the Director of Public
Works or his designee.
   D.   Unauthorized Removal or Relocation: No person shall remove or relocate
a refuse container of any size or type provided by the City or its designated
collector unless permission for removal or relocation is duly authorized by
proper authority. Owners or occupants shall report any container that has been
removed from the assigned premises on the next business day following discovery
of said missing container, or as soon as practicable.
   E.   Violation. Any person who knowingly or maliciously removes or relocates
a refuse container in violation of these provisions shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and punished in accordance as provided in Section
1-1-8 of this Code. Said violator may also be assessed the cost of repairing or
replacing said container as may be applicable.
   F.   Enforcement: Notwithstanding the enforcement provisions set forth in
Section
17-4-2 of this Code, any code enforcement official employed by the City is
vested with the authority to enforce any provision of this chapter as set forth
herein. (2000 Code § 17-407; amd. Ord. 1081, 4-8-2008, eff. 5-8-2008; Ord.
1271, 8-9-2022)
17-4-8: COMMERCIAL REFUSE COLLECTIONS; CONTAINERS; FEES:
   A.   Garbage Collection Rates:
      1.   For the purpose of defraying the expense of the collection of
garbage and the removal of garbage, trash and debris from the various
commercial and business establishments with the city, the utilities office of
the city is hereby authorized and directed to collect from each owner or
occupant of each business or commercial establishment as the case may be within
the city the following fees and charges per month:
COMMERCIAL

                            Weekly  Weekly  Weekly  Weekly  Weekly  Weekly

   1.    Downtown is defined as:
      East Alley, beginning at Osage Street, North to Seminole Avenue, running
between Fourth Street and Main Street.
      Middle Alley, beginning at Osage Street, North to Seminole Avenue, and
running between Main and Second Streets.
      West Alley, beginning at Osage Street, North to Seminole Avenue, running
between Second Street and Milt Phillips Avenue.
ROLL-OFF SERVICES

(Up to 30 days)

10 cubic yards            $334.18
